          • Randy M says:
            February 13, 2018 at 3:24 pm

            After years of marriage, he realized his wife was a secret nudist when she gave birth to naked babies.
            Shocking twist–she actually cheated on him with a nudist.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 4:29 pm

            @Le Maistre Chat: Which do you find more likely: that a lot of gay/trans people pretended to be straight/cis when there were extreme negative consequences to being openly gay/trans? Or that a lot of straight/cis people are now pretending to be gay/trans, despite there being no real benefits to doing so, because the negative consequences for being openly gay/trans are no longer as extreme as they used to be?

            Not to mention, trans people living in a society where there wasn’t even a concept of “transgender” would probably have a great deal of difficulty figuring out how to even contextualize their feelings of dysphoria. Also, plenty of intersex people aren’t actually aware that they’re intersex, even today, and I’d imagine that it would’ve been a lot less likely for them to find out without modern medical testing.

          • Matt M says:
            February 13, 2018 at 4:50 pm

            despite there being no real benefits to doing so,

            Disagree. There are definitely some social circles in which identifying as gay or trans increases ones status significantly. And plenty of non-social situations as well (college applications, job applications, diversity in procurement requirements, etc.)

            And these spheres seem to be increasing, not decreasing.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:54 pm

            Also, plenty of intersex people aren’t actually aware that they’re intersex, even today, and I’d imagine that it would’ve been a lot less likely for them to find out without modern medical testing.

            If I understand you correctly, you are using “intersex” to cover a bunch of different things. A short list:

            1. A hermaphrodite–someone with both male and female genitals.

            2. A transsexual–someone whose body is unambiguously of one gender but who identifies as the other.

            3. Someone with non-standard genetics. XXY is the most common but, as you probably know, others exist. Mostly such people appear as somewhat atypical males or females.

            There may well be more I haven’t thought of. I should probably include a Tumtum, since the ancient Jews did (along with hermaphrodites–both raised puzzles for the application of religious law). But I’m not certain what one was and it probably is due to a problem that can be eliminated by modern medicine.

            These different categories raise different issues, so lumping them together makes discussion more difficult.

          • liskantope says:
            February 13, 2018 at 11:43 pm

            There’s this place called tumblr, you see. And…

            Not sure what is meant to be proven through the link on “And…”, unless I’m not reading enough of the website.

          • Aapje says:
            February 14, 2018 at 2:24 am

            @liskantope

            This video may be illuminating. Danielle often wears a beard, has a super low voice, is balding and otherwise presents 100% like a man, but claims to be a transwoman. You can also see an apparent non-effort to appear female in the photos at the bottom of this page.

            As you can see at Danielle’s site, this person seems to use the trans/female identity to get to speak on behalf of trans people/women in a way that a man would often not be allowed to, in the blue tribe. In fact, this seems to be Danielle’s career.

            So it seems possible/likely that the trans identity gave Danielle access to a SJ advocacy career.

          • Barely matters says:
            February 14, 2018 at 8:27 am

            despite there being no real benefits to doing so

            So, this is both exactly the kind of story that this account is for (Ridiculous, probably offensive to some, and definitely of the stripe that I know better than to tell at work), and relevant here.

            A partner that I dated for roughly 4 years recently came out as nominally trans. They’re still entirely physically female and have said they have no plans to physically or hormonally transition at all. All of this comes on the heels of an official borderline diagnosis while having plunged deep into the fetlife scene. Extrapolate at your leisure.

            Where it gets interesting is that they say they’ve always been trans, but are only coming out with it now, which means I was retroactively in a gay relationship for several years. I presume they’re telling me this because they think it’ll get under my skin, cithet hegemonic scum that I am, but let’s be cereal for a moment here: This is absolutely fucking hilarious!

            Since then, I’ve been able to preface points with “As a gay man, I feel that…” in discussions with my other friends who’ve frequently pulled out this gambit in the past. Whereas previously it would shut down discussion, because who am I to contradict the lived experience of my more fabulous compatriots? But now it lets me meet that particular powerplay with an equivalent and continue speaking as an equal. It’s eye opening.

            Having never experienced the ability to make arguments that are privileged by virtue of the disprivilege of the speaker before, I can see the appeal! At this point I can safely say that anyone claiming that there are not real social power benefits to having a dispriviliged identity in modern society is lying, full stop. The power involved becomes apparent seconds after deploying it for the first time. And while I’d prefer we all just ditched identity based power games altogether, I’m flexible, y’know?

          • liskantope says:
            February 14, 2018 at 2:25 pm

            @Aapje: I’m listening to the video you linked to, ~18 minutes in (probably won’t watch the whole thing). While I don’t doubt that some people who call themselves trans don’t actually have gender dysphoria, I don’t see great evidence from the video that Danielle Muscato, who claims to have been diagnosed with gender dysphoria and making small changes with the advice of a therapist but to be unable to go through hormones and full transition for health reasons.

          • Aapje says:
            February 15, 2018 at 2:51 am

            @liskantope

            That sounds like BS to me. Is there a health condition that makes it impossible to use hormones AND impossible to smoothly shave and impossible to grow out your hair or wear a wig and to wear a little makeup and …

            Muscato also makes conflicting statements, for example, claiming to be prevented from transitioning due to expenses and difficulty getting hormones, 6 months after claiming to have medical reasons to not be able to transition.

            It seems extremely unlikely that one would announce in 2014 to want to gradually transition entirely without mentioning any medical issues that may prevent that and then know in December of 2016 that one cannot take hormones due to medical reasons, without actually trying to transition by taking hormones in the meantime. However, in that case it makes zero sense to claim in May of 2016 that one does not have access to hormones for multiple reasons. Are we supposed to believe that those multiple reasons all dissipated in less than 6 months?

            The evidence that I see suggests insincerity much more than another explanation.

      • Adrian says:
        February 12, 2018 at 4:41 am

        Freedom of speech does not equate to freedom from the consequences of that speech, such as getting reprimanded or fired […]

        Yes, it does, otherwise it’s not freedom of speech. “You’re free to criticize the regime, comrade, but that doesn’t free you from the consequence of being sent to the gulag.”
        What is your definition of “freedom of speech”, then?

        just like I consider “trans people’s gender identities aren’t valid” to be as offensive and inaccurate as “non-whites are physically and mentally inferior to whites.”

        How can you reach a public consensus for that idea when you censor all debate on that topic? Because there’s certainly no broad consensus that “trans people’s gender identities aren’t valid” is a false statement.

        • Ketil says:
          February 12, 2018 at 5:23 am

          I think the interpretation of “freedom of speech” is one which applies to government suppression of speech only. Employers are free to fire you (and your children can be kicked out of school, stores can refuse you service, etc, etc) if you express (or are suspected of subscribing to) undesirable views – or in this case, fail to express the views deemed correct.

          Obviously, this kind of lynch mob mentality can be just as stifling for political discourse and debate as governmental censorship, but by using this definition, we can still claim “free speech”.

          • The original Mr. X says:
            February 12, 2018 at 6:51 am

            I’d be much more sympathetic to such arguments if the people proposing them used them across the board. E.g., “Freedom from discrimination only covers government discrimination; as long as the government isn’t passing laws discriminating against a certain race, private businessmen should be free not to serve them.”

            (And, on a more quibbling note, I think “your children can be kicked out of school” would still count as government suppression of free speech, at least if you’re one of the vast majority of people whose children go to state schools.)

          • Murphy says:
            February 12, 2018 at 9:10 am

            That becomes a little more awkward when the employer is the government. (as in this case since she’s an employee of a public university getting government funding)

            Should the government be allowed fire employees for publicly campaigning for the opposition party in their free time?

            How about for failing to criticize the opposition parties position in a video shown to a class while on the clock?

            “Freedom of speech does not equate to freedom from the consequences” becomes vastly vastly more worrying when the state employe a sizable fraction of the working population and can suddenly inflict “consequences” on employees who don’t toe the party line hard enough.

          • SamChevre says:
            February 12, 2018 at 10:13 am

            I would agree, and would strengthen what you said: free speech applies to government suppression of speech, direct or indirect.

            Direct: blasphemy laws, anti-sedition laws, etc.

            Indirect: “if you hire people who hold those views, or won’t hire people who hold these views, you can be punished–you may find it difficult to get business licenses, or be fined, or…

            I’m very OK with any private business deciding that it doesn’t want employees who refuse to use its customers preferred pronouns working there: but if the government requires it to ensure that it’s employees do so, that’s not free speech. (I’m similarly OK with private businesses only hiring people who think the whole notion of transgender is nonsense. Or only people who think the only proper breakfast is congee. It’s not the government’s business.)

          • LadyJane says:
            February 12, 2018 at 1:05 pm

            @Adrian, @Ketil: I’ll freely admit, I’m exactly the kind of libertarian that Scott complains about in https://slatestarcodex.com/2017/07/29/against-signal-boosting-as-doxxing/. He thinks it contradicts the spirit of libertarian ideals, if not the letter. I think his view unfairly favors the people making unpopular arguments, and limits the freedom of speech and freedom of association of the people responding to them. The marketplace of ideas is exactly that, a marketplace, and there are (and should be!) consequences to failure there. Those consequences just shouldn’t be enforced by the state at gunpoint.

            And among the scientific and medical establishment, there is indeed a broad consensus that “trans people’s gender identities aren’t valid” is a false statement, as I explained in my reply to Winter Shaker above. That consensus might not exist among the general populace, but who cares? 42% of Americans don’t believe in evolution either, that doesn’t mean the issue is still up for debate in any serious academic context.

            @The original Mr. X: If it makes any difference, I think anti-discrimination laws should only apply to government agencies and contractors.

            @Murphy: I would say that, as a general rule, government employers should not be allowed to fire employees for not supporting the current political establishment. I would also say there should be exceptions for cases where not supporting the current political (or academic/scientific establishment) would directly interfere with the function of the job. For instance, I would expect a press secretary who publicly denounced the politician he was supposed to be representing to be fired in short order, and I wouldn’t expect a government-funded climate research institute to hire a climate change denialist. Likewise, I think it’s acceptable for a government-funded university to punish a professor who taught outdated psychological theories like Blanchardism.

            @SamChevre: I mostly agree. Although, as I explained above, I think deliberately and constantly misgendering a specific individual is tantamount to harassment, and I would consider that valid grounds for a civil suit.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 12, 2018 at 6:21 pm

            And among the scientific and medical establishment, there is indeed a broad consensus that “trans people’s gender identities aren’t valid” is a false statement, as I explained in my reply to Winter Shaker above.

            What is a valid gender identity is not a question on which the scientific and medical establishment has any special expertise. If what I mean by “gender” is genetic gender then their gender identity is not valid. If what I mean by “female gender” is “does not think of self as male” (etc.) then it is.

          • Murphy says:
            February 13, 2018 at 3:34 am

            @LadyJane

            It’s a tad suspicious that all the exceptions you carve seem to favor one political ideology while all the things you take a hard line of disfavor it’s opponent.

            It’s like a chirstian who claims to be all about areligious principles and tolerance but happens to support laws that happen to ban the traditional garb of other religions but carves out exceptions for any times when their own religion calls for wearing things that would otherwise violate the rules.

          • honhonhonhon says:
            February 13, 2018 at 4:44 am

            I don’t think that kind of personal attack is fashionable here Murphy.

          • Murphy says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:55 am

            @honhonhonhon

            Is there a nicer way to express that someone seems to be carving carefully around their own ideology or markers for their own social group?

            deciding that saying things [popular with their own social group] and unpopular with [ideological group popular with the other 50% of the population] are where free speech is right and proper to apply

            but that saying things [unpopular with their own social group] and popular with [ideological group popular with the other 50% of the population] is where we need to take and stand and suppress things.

          • honhonhonhon says:
            February 13, 2018 at 8:05 am

            No, because the thing you’re trying to express is itself not nice. You’re assuming that the other side is intentionally favoring unprincipled solutions. A lot of people instinctively prefer rules that favor them in the moment, but that’s different in intent from “yeah I’m carefully making unprincipled rules here so my side wins”. The instinctive group is engaged by building a thought experiment where the rules apply against them, the intentional villain group is engaged by discussion about the futility of villainy, but you only engage the audience by announcing “you unprincipled villain!” (a real villain wouldn’t care or would think you a loser, and someone unintentionally doing it would be discouraged from maintaining the same good faith and civility in debate as before the allegation)

      • Aapje says:
        February 12, 2018 at 5:23 am

        @LadyJane

        You seem to view my framing of the issue as a free speech issue to be a disingenuous attempt to argue for the right to harm a person.

        However, what we see in the Shepherd case is that she was not reprimanded for misgendering anyone, nor for showing a clip where a person was misgendered, but rather for showing a clip where Peterson argued on the meta level. I agree with you that, at the object level, certain behaviors should be outlawed/punished/etc. However, I believe that it is crucial for a free society that one should always be allowed to argue that the law is wrong.

        Fundamentally, arguing that a law is wrong, without breaking the law, does no direct harm, except the offense that is taken. For example, while a person who is denied a job for her race is harmed in the opportunity that she has been denied, merely hearing someone advocate for the right to deny her a job does not in itself cause direct harm. Indirect harm, like other people being convinced that the law is wrong and undoing it, is something that in my view best handled by having the opponents make their best case and having society make a democratic decision. Abandoning that solution generally leads to a ‘benevolent dictatorship’ (in the eyes of those who rule), which is often not considered very benevolent by the ruled.

        As such, my worry about the implication to free speech is not (just) a way to resist a certain object-level policy, but rather, it is what I care about most. In fact, it is the conflation of the object level with the meta-level, which we see in the Shepherd case, in your comment and among a certain portion of society, which makes me far more wary to extend protections. What I see is exactly the opposite of what you worry about: that arguments at the object level are used to push through bad changes on the meta level.

        —

        A second issue is that I don’t believe that protecting people is as black & white as you claim. For example, let’s take your claim that we should ban people from arguing that a particular race is inherently superior or inferior. The problem here is that this can be counter to the scientific evidence and (therefor) make it harder for us to help people.

        I believe that my light skin makes me objectively inferior at living in places where the sun shines very brightly, while it makes me objectively superior at living in places where the sun shines less. Disallowing me to argue this, effectively makes it impossible for me to argue that people with light skin color should more often use sunscreen & that people with dark skin color should more often take vitamin D supplements, even though such race-based advice seems appropriate.

        Another example that demonstrates the difficulty in making general rules, is that people in some black subcultures like to call each other by the n-word. People are diverse, with different culture, different relationships to each other, etc; so it is hard it make good rules. Perhaps transwoman 1 never wants to be called a ‘he,’ but transwoman 2 actually prefers that transphobes call her that, so she knows to be wary of them, rather than have the prejudice affect her in more subtle ways that are hard for her to see, but which do much harm. So instead of top-level rules, it may be better to push such rules to the communitarian level as much as possible, based on the self-organizing ability of people.

        I also don’t particularly trust authorities, other than judges, to properly navigate these nuances, especially since (significantly) erring in the direction of a stifling environment tends to be the most pleasant to them (easier and requiring less effort, at least, at first).

        While I agree with you that it is not necessarily wrong for organizations to pick a side, it is important that we then allow multiple sides to exist in separate organizations. Where this is not possible, we should demand neutrality (or at least, democratically backed decisions) as much as possible. This is true in particular for public and semi-public organizations, because there is only one state. I consider colleges to be semi-public organizations, given that even ‘private colleges’ tend to get much of their funding from the state & that we see in practice that the state leverages this to force the colleges into adopting certain policies.

        • albatross11 says:
          February 12, 2018 at 8:40 am

          Lady Jane:

          In the US, the first amendment also applies to government-run schools (state universities, for example), so a state university probably could get in first-amendment trouble for imposing rules restricting what viewpoints were welcome on campus. I have no idea how that works in Canada, though.

          On the object-level questions you mentioned, I think you are making a tradeoff, and you should be open about that tradeoff.

          a. On one side, some discussions, questions of fact, or intellectual inquiries will offend the hell out of some people.

          b. On the other side, suppressing those discussions, questions of fact, or intellectual inquiries will probably block off some paths of learning new things about the world.

          As a pretty simple case of this, consider the theory of evolution. To advocate for this theory was to call into question the most deeply held beliefs of a big chunk of the population, including most of the students at any university at the time it was beginning to be taught and researched. A lot of authorities wanted to suppress these discussions and inquiries, either to avoid offending these people, or for fear that undermining traditional beliefs about religion and morality would lead to a lot of social problems. But if those efforts had been successful, we would be enormously worse off right now.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 12, 2018 at 8:45 am

            And it is important to remember that the people trying to suppress speech about evolution thought they were doing the right, socially responsible thing.

            It isn’t enough to think you are right, this time, and they were wrong. Nobody thinks that that doesn’t apply to them.

          • dndnrsn says:
            February 12, 2018 at 9:19 am

            Bah, I posted something about this, but you got to it first. Most Canadian universities are public; Wilfred Laurier is. We have fewer speech protections than the US; the hate speech type laws in Canada would never fly in the US. I believe Peterson is on the record as saying he supports the current Canadian system – he’s OK with banning speech, but not with compelled speech, I think.

            So, rather amusingly, a “free speech crusader” in Canada holds basically the same opinion as someone against free speech in the US.

      • Matt M says:
        February 12, 2018 at 9:38 am

        If someone kept insisting that one of their cis male co-workers was a woman, and exclusively referred to them by female pronouns, that would be seen as extremely rude and unprofessional behavior, and could easily get that person fired if they continued to do it.

        Because if they did that with one person and with no one else, it would be seen as bullying (and it would be).

        Someone who adopts, as a general framing of the world, the idea of “gender is not a social construct” and chooses to refer to everybody based on the pronouns of the gender they were born with is doing no such thing.

        The former is a bully who is picking on one person and deserves to be punished. The latter is someone who simply has a different worldview.

        • LadyJane says:
          February 12, 2018 at 1:14 pm

          If someone adopts, as a general framing of the world, the idea of “non-whites are subhuman inferior races who are undeserving of respect,” that doesn’t make it socially acceptable for them to start insulting every African and Asian person they meet.

          You’re free to believe whatever you want, and to express those beliefs, but when you start treating specific people disrespectfully because of those beliefs, then you’re engaging in targeted harassment. (There’s a reason that this forum prohibits misgendering specific posters, despite allowing debate over the validity of trans identities in general.)

          • Matt M says:
            February 12, 2018 at 1:27 pm

            You’re introducing an analogy of inferiority and disrespect where none exists.

            If my general policy is to identify people based on their biological sex – that is not claiming they are inferior in any way, nor is it treating them disrespectfully.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 12, 2018 at 1:31 pm

            Unless you’re going to do chromosomal testing on everyone you meet, that doesn’t really hold water.

          • Matt M says:
            February 12, 2018 at 1:33 pm

            Sure. I suspect that people who make a great deal of effort to pass are very rarely misgendered by complete strangers.

            But if you’re unwilling to put in that level of effort. If you still appear, to most people, to be a man, then don’t be surprised if you get called and treated like a man.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 12, 2018 at 6:28 pm

            You’re free to believe whatever you want, and to express those beliefs, but when you start treating specific people disrespectfully because of those beliefs, then you’re engaging in targeted harassment.

            So if you treat people who don’t believe in evolution disrespectfully because of your beliefs about the subject–make it clear that you think they are scientifically ignorant–you are engaged in targeted harassment?

            If you treat people who believe that gender is defined biologically disrespectfully, insist that they are ignorant people defying a correct scientific consensus–which is pretty close to what you have just been doing–that too is targeted harassment?

            I am not entitled to have people respect me. The inside of their heads, which is where their view of me resides, belongs to them. Nor am I entitled to have people lie about their beliefs to keep me from being offended by them.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 12, 2018 at 7:47 pm

            If I had a co-worker who didn’t believe in evolution, and I kept referring to him as “creationist” in every single interaction with him, and prefaced every statement about him by saying “he’s a creationist,” then yes, that would count as targeted harassment and most employers would agree. That might seem like an extreme example, but if you’re misgendering someone on every single occasion in which you talk to or about them, then it’s every bit as relentless and pervasive as the situation I described.

            People are not entitled to respect. But I would say that they’re entitled to being treated respectfully, or at the very least, entitled to not being treated with active disrespect on a constant basis.

          • Jiro says:
            February 13, 2018 at 2:52 pm

            If you kept calling the guy a creationist whenever you were going to use a word related to him being a creationist anyway would it be harassment?

            Pronouns come up a lot more in conversation than “creationist”.

      • Le Maistre Chat says:
        February 12, 2018 at 12:12 pm

        Public universities are at least a de facto part of the government, so being fired or in any way punished for exercising free speech by them should be unconstitutional.

      • a reader says:
        February 13, 2018 at 5:06 am

        @LadyJane:

        Are you a rationalist? If yes, pls say with me:

        If Blanchard’s theory is right
        I desire to believe that Blanchard’s theory is right;
        If Blanchard’s theory is wrong,
        I desire to believe that Blanchard’s theory is wrong;
        Let me not become attached to beliefs I may not want.

        If there are genetic IQ differences between races,
        I desire to believe that there are genetic IQ differences between races;
        If there are no genetic IQ differences between races,
        I desire to believe that there are no genetic IQ differences between races;
        Let me not become attached to beliefs I may not want.

        (Litany of Tarski adapted)

        What is true is already so.
        Owning up to it doesn’t make it worse.
        Not being open about it doesn’t make it go away.
        And because it’s true, it is what is there to be interacted with.
        Anything untrue isn’t there to be lived.
        People can stand what is true,
        for they are already enduring it.

        (Litany of Gendlin)

        Both those debates are as yet far from settled – you find contemporary experts on both sides – so it is very premature to treat them like evolutionism vs creationism. It is dangerous for science, for truth-seeking and problem-solving, to treat unsettled debates as settled for the side you preffer and impose your prefference on all researchers, to accept it or risk ostracism.

        If there are really no genetic IQ differences between races, then no genes but more and more environmental factors will be discovered, until all the IQ gap between races will be explained and those in charge will know how to make it dissapear completely by environmental interventions.

        But if there are in fact some genetic IQ differences between races and those in charge proclaim that there are not, after all possible environmental factors are discovered and eliminated, a (somewhat reduced) IQ gap is still there and there’s nothing you cand do about it as long as you mantain your paradigm. But if scientists (are allowed to) consider that there may be genetic differences, then they can think of genetic interventions that can succesfully close the gap.

        Similarly, if Blanchard’s theory about the two types of transwomen is false, if type 2 MTF trans (that he called “autogynephiles”) are actually similar with type 1 MTF trans (that he called “homosexual transsexuals”), only more repressed, so that they accept themselves and transition later, then the best strategy would be to discover them earlier, at 18-20, when a really succesful transition may be still possible.

        But if Blanchard’s theory about the two types of transwomen is true, if the two types of MTF transsexuals are really different phenomena with different causes, maybe transition will still be the best solution for type 1 MTF trans (who transition early and successfully, passing quite easily as women) and a different solution (maybe an anti-dysphoria pill) may be found for type 2 MTF transsexuals, who transition late and have big difficulties in passing as women (not only physically but even psychologically they are very atypical for women: they are frequently programmers and/or atheists, groups in which women are visibly underrepresented).

        Sorry if I made any language errors – I am not a native English speaker.

        • Thegnskald says:
          February 13, 2018 at 5:26 am

          Please don’t troll.

          And if you aren’t trolling, and you genuinely think that bringing up that can of worms is likely to convince anybody of your perspective, rather than provide an excuse for you to feel superior to them for rejecting it as racism – then I have a litany for you;

          If I don’t understand how people work, I desire to believe that I don’t understand how people work. If I do understand how people work, yada yada yada.

          Which is to say, you are either a troll or have such a, to be blunt, terrible model of how other people think, that this discussion cannot be fruitful.

          (Which is not to say that a productive discussion cannot be had, only that you have made it harder, not easier, to have one.)

          • a reader says:
            February 13, 2018 at 5:43 am

            I don’t troll. Of course I sometimes don’t understand how other people work – for example I don’t understand why you seem to believe I am trolling. You didn’t explain what (do you consider) I did wrong, what rule I didn’t follow. Scott didn’t say that this is a “no culture war thread” and the culture war subjects were touched by others before me. Controversial subjects are touched frequently by Scott himself and by many commentators – and you proclaimed your suport for Marxism without anybody accusing you of trolling, if I remember well (if not, sorry). So what seemed trolling to you?

            As I said, I am not an American. I come from a quite different culture (Eastern Europe).

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 5:47 am

            Bringing up an unrelated and highly contentious topic which is itself, although not entirely banned, on the “tread carefully” list, as evidenced by it’s most common nomenclature being banned terms.

            I get that a certain group of people use it as a litmus test for whether or not somebody is objective and rational enough to have a civilized discussion with.

            I also get that it doubles as a Beck’s Razor, which is to say, something that pisses people off to the point where they can’t make coherent arguments and “lose” by default.

            Neither is appropriate in this context, and the latter is just a more elaborate and self-justified form of trolling.

            ETA: Which is to say, it is the fact that you brought up an unrelated culture war topic out of nowhere, in an ongoing culture war topic, which reads as blatant trolling. There is literally no reason to bring it up.

          • a reader says:
            February 13, 2018 at 5:58 am

            But I didn’t bring it up first and out of nowhere – LadyJane did, in the first paragraph of her first comment on this subthread ( the comment I was responding to):

            I fail to see the problem. It’s perfectly fine for universities to take sides, and prohibiting teachers from expressing certain points of view (e.g. that a particular race is inherently superior or inferior) is well within their rights

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:03 am

            I don’t think LadyJane was talking about the same thing you are talking about, but fair enough, I guess; I apologize and withdraw the objection.

        • LadyJane says:
          February 13, 2018 at 10:28 am

          “It is dangerous for science, for truth-seeking and problem-solving, to treat unsettled debates as settled for the side you preffer and impose your prefference on all researchers, to accept it or risk ostracism.”

          It’s also dangerous for science to treat debates that are mostly settled as being completely unsettled just because there’s some doubt about some of the exact particulars. It’s dangerous to act as if both sides of a debate are equally valid when the evidence strongly favors one over the other, just to maintain some artificial sense of fairness and balance. That’s why you have people saying that the verdict on climate change isn’t out yet, despite the fact that 97% of climate scientists believe it’s real. Or schools that try to “teach the controversy” about creationism and evolution, as if both are equally likely.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 11:12 am

            despite the fact that 97% of climate scientists believe it’s real.

            I’m curious. Have you read the article that claim is usually based on (Cook et. al. 2013)? Do you know what the substance of the claim is?

            I ask because most people who refer to it haven’t and don’t, which points to part of the problem with your position. The mechanisms by which something gets viewed as the truth all well informed people know are quite unreliable, leading people to hold views with considerably greater certainty than the evidence supports. That problem is increased when there is pressure, legal or social, not to argue against the current orthodoxy.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:29 pm

            @DavidFriedman: I’m aware that, among the 97% of scientists who agree with anthropogenic climate change, there’s a great deal of debate about the degree to which climate change is anthropogenic vs. natural, as well as the severity of both climate change itself and the consequences likely to result from it. I’ll admit to being something of a “lukewarmist” myself, and I generally think our responses to climate change should be tempered by other (economic, political, social, etc.) concerns.

            But that’s exactly what I mean about not treating debates as completely unsettled just because there are some points of doubt and disagreement. 97% of climate scientists might not agree on everything in regards to climate change, but they all agree that the hard denialist position is wrong. Evolutionary biologists might have some difficulty explaining how particular species or organic structures evolved, but they all agree that the answer isn’t “God created the Earth and all of its lifeforms in 7 days.” And neuropsychologists might not know the exact mechanisms that cause people to be homosexual or transgender, but they know there’s definitely a very strong biological component there and it’s not just sociocultural.

          • a reader says:
            February 13, 2018 at 1:15 pm

            @LadyJane:

            There is a creationist biochemistry profesor named Michael Behe. According to Wikipedia, he claims “that some biochemical structures are too complex to be explained by known evolutionary mechanisms and are therefore probably the result of intelligent design.” Also according to Wikipedia:

            Behe’s claims about the irreducible complexity of essential cellular structures have been rejected by the vast majority of the scientific community,[4][5] and his own biology department at Lehigh University published an official statement opposing Behe’s views and intelligent design.

            But I don’t remember ever hearing about Behe being fired or having his course canceled for expressing his ideas, being harassed by furious student mobs or having his children cruelly ridiculed online by cyberbullies just because they are his children.

            That’s why I can be sure that the scientific consensus about evolution is a real consensus: scientists have nothing to be afraid of in their personal life if they publicly reject evolution, so they publicly support it because they privately sincerely believe in it.

            You said that:

            universities should not endorse something like Blanchardism as the correct theory or even as a possible correct theory, not just because it’s offensive, but also because it’s just plain wrong (at least according to the vast majority of the modern scientific and medical establishment). It’s the same reason that universities shouldn’t endorse creationism as correct or possibly correct.

            Link please? You could easily provide a link to prove that creationism and climate change denial are rejected by “the vast majority of the modern scientific establishment” – could you do the same about “Blanchardism” as you called it? Can you prove it is 97% consensus, like that about climate change? Or at least 90% consensus? If you find, let’s say, around 60% consensus, that doesn’t mean “the vast majority of the modern scientific establishment”, that means the theory is still under debate.

            Of course, we won’t find many public supporters of “Blanchardism” among US academics – but that isn’t surprising at all, when its most known American supporter, prof. J. Michael Bailey, had his children cruelly ridiculed online by some trans cyberbully (his course about sexuality at Northwestern University was canceled, but for a seemingly unrelated reason).

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 2:49 pm

            97% of climate scientists might not agree on everything in regards to climate change, but they all agree that the hard denialist position is wrong.

            The 97% wasn’t a count of climate scientists. It was a count of article abstracts. And it wasn’t that 97% of the abstracts said warming was anthropogenic, it was that of the abstracts that expressed an opinion on the subject–a minority–97% said or implied that humans were one of the causes.

            That doesn’t refute the point you make, that very few climate scientists believe human action has no effect on climate, but it does support the point I was making, that factoids about such issues, such as the one you referred to, provide low quality information, hence it is risky to base one’s views of what issues are or are not settled on them.

            You wrote:

            That’s why you have people saying that the verdict on climate change isn’t out yet

            A view you apparently agree with, as do I.

            You have very few people saying that humans have no effect on climate and I doubt that if anyone does say that it’s to “maintain some artificial sense of fairness and balance.” More likely it is some combination of true belief and contrarianism.

            But you do see lots of people treating unsettled debates about climate science as settled, many of them treating as obviously true claims that go far beyond the IPCC reports. And you saw the same thing on population issues fifty years ago.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 3:19 pm

            “The 97% wasn’t a count of climate scientists. It was a count of article abstracts. And it wasn’t that 97% of the abstracts said warming was anthropogenic, it was that of the abstracts that expressed an opinion on the subject–a minority–97% said or implied that humans were one of the causes.”

            I stand corrected. Thank you for the clarification. But I think my larger point still stands.

            At the risk of delving far too deep into abstractions: Imagine there are two theories on a subject, Theory 1 and Theory 2. An overwhelming majority of scientists agree that Theory 2 is definitely false, and even if the truth is somewhere in-between, it’s going to be much closer to the Theory 1 side of the argument. Now imagine some ‘clever’ skeptic decides to argue that “since scientists can’t choose between Theory 1.0-A, Theory 1.0-B, and Theory 1.25, and there’s a small minority of scientists who even believe Theory 1.5, that means the issue isn’t settled yet, so Theory 1.75 or Theory 2.0 could be true too, they’re all equally valid!” I would consider that kind of argument to be ignorant at best and intellectually dishonest at worst, and I certainly wouldn’t consider it to be in keeping with the principles of rationality.

            Reader’s initial post, the one with the litanies, strikes me as being analogous to that kind of ‘logic.’

          • a reader says:
            February 14, 2018 at 2:09 am

            @LadyJane:

            I would consider that kind of argument to be ignorant at best and intellectually dishonest at worst, and I certainly wouldn’t consider it to be in keeping with the principles of rationality.

            Reader’s initial post, the one with the litanies, strikes me as being analogous to that kind of ‘logic.’

            I thought about dropping the too inflamable subject of race and IQ, but after my post is accused of being “ignorant at best and intellectually dishonest at worst”, I am forced to come back at it.

            From a Survey of Expert Opinion on Intelligence and Aptitude Testing by M. Snyderman and S. Rothman, collected in 1984 (page 141):

            The source of the black-white difference in IQ. This is perhaps the central question in the IQ controversy. Respondents were asked to express their opinion of the role of genetic differences in the black-white IQ differential. Forty-five percent believe the difference to be a product of both genetic and environmental variation, compared to only 15% who feel the difference is entirely due to environmental variation. Twenty-four percent of experts do not believe there are sufficient data to support any reasonable opinion, and 14% did not respond to the question. Eight experts (1%) indicate a belief in an entirely genetic determination.

            From its more recent replication, 2013 survey of expert opinion
            on intelligence             by H. Rindermann, T. R. Coyle and D. Becker (page 16):

            Sources of U.S. black-white differences in IQ

            0-40% of differences due to genes: 42% of experts
            0% of differences due to genes: (17% of experts)
            [1-40% of differences due to genes: (25% of experts)]
            50% of differences due to genes: 18% of experts
            60-100% of differences due to genes: 39% of experts
            [60-99% of differences due to genes: (34% of experts)]
            100% of differences due to genes: (5% of experts)
            M=47% of differences due to genes (SD=31%)

            (the lines in [] are calculated by myself from the other lines, by simple aritmetic, the others are quoted)

            So, as you can see, not only the debate is really not settled yet, there is no consensus about that subject, but when the scientists are surveyed anonymously, a very different picture emerges than the one media presents us as “the scientific consensus”.

            I’ll write a different post about the (lack of) scientific consensus about “Blanchardism”, because if I put more than 2 links in a comment, it ends in spam.

          • Aapje says:
            February 14, 2018 at 2:55 am

            The ‘scientific consensus’ is probably becoming less reliable and harder to accurate gauge due to increasing academic homogeneity. This can result in broadly held biases, but also in people refusing to speak their mind, out of fear of being punished for stating things that are not acceptable to most progressives.

            Note that this argument is often interpreted as a complaint about a lack of conservatives at colleges, but the evidence actually shows that moderates are declining just as much as conservatives, which is far more worrisome than if conservatives would be replaced by mostly moderates.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 14, 2018 at 11:50 am

            The ‘scientific consensus’ is probably becoming less reliable and harder to accurate gauge due to increasing academic homogeneity.

            That’s part of the problem. Another part is that, because “scientific consensus” is used as a political weapon, there is an incentive for people who care about an issue to try to get in a position to control what statements are made by scientific organizations.

          • Paul Zrimsek says:
            February 14, 2018 at 1:08 pm

            Plus, Goodhart’s law. “Scientific consensus” is getting less and less measurey and more and more targety.

    • liskantope says:
      February 12, 2018 at 4:16 am

      I also only found out about this recently, thought of bringing it up on the next OT but wasn’t sure if I wanted the responsibility of causing the comments section to explode 😛

      I’ll just copy-and-paste what I posted the other day on Tumblr:

      I’m kind of surprised that I haven’t seen any mention on Tumblr or on Slate Star Codex of this audio tape (which I ran across on YouTube in connection with Jordan Peterson), which was secretly recorded by a young grad student who had been summoned to be reprimanded by the professor running the course she was teaching along with some diversity ombudsmen. This was in reaction to an informal complaint they had received about the fact that she showed a brief YouTube clip of Jordan Peterson arguing about gender-neutral pronouns, which she had neither endorsed nor condemned. (It came out later that no actual complaint, either formal or informal, had been submitted to that crew from a student – it had come from a representative from some campus LGBTQ center who had heard one student expressing concern about it in casual conversation.)

      Several partially-developed thoughts about the whole scandal and particularly this audio clip. On the one hand, this is the starkest evidence – from a primary source! – of the kind of SJ-flavored suppression of ideas from even being voiced at universities that more and more people are expressing concern about. I consider myself generally pro-trans-rights* and am taking more issue with Dr. Peterson’s views the more of his content I’ve seen in the last few days. But I still find listening to him worthwhile in that it makes me think critically about points I may not have considered and to sharpen and refine my “generally pro-trans” views on the complex questions involved with gender identity. I can understand that certain clips of his rhetoric might be distressing to some trans people (I don’t think she picked one of the more provoking ones), but to claim that the act of merely exposing the students to a snippet of Dr. Peterson is a form “gendered violence” or denying trans students the right to “be human”, seems like quite a stretch – in my less charitable moments, I’m even tempted to call it absurd.

      On the other hand, I have some disagreements with the grad student Lindsay Shepherd’s point of view as well. My biggest issue is with her statement that “in a university, all perspectives are valid”. The first time she said it, I chalked it down to a poor explanation of her view due to the stress of being put on the spot, but she repeated it later. No, not all perspectives are valid, or at least not equally valid, and I’m not in favor of presenting them as such at a university. The “all perspectives are valid” mentality reminds me of the rhetoric coming from advocates of teaching creationism Intelligent Design in schools (”Teach both sides of the controversy!”). There is no way to present all the perspectives out there – even all the ones with a significant amount of clout in the public discourse – in neutral and even-handed way. A university instructor’s choices of which points of view to teach have to be informed by the scholarly merit of each point of view out there. Yeah, certain areas of academic inquiry might be stifled by bias in academia – I’m getting more and more worried that this is the case in some social science departments – and this is a problem. But just tossing out “All perspectives are valid!” neither proves that this bias is happening nor solves this problem.

      A much more minor and subtle criticism I would make of Shepherd’s words is that I’ve heard her at a couple of points in interviews expressing an attitude that roughly goes “I like listening to people like Jordan Peterson even if I disagree with him, because I find people like that interesting and their ideas fascinating to ponder, it’s something I really enjoy doing.” On the surface this seems all right (and I came dangerously close to expressing the same attitude a couple of paragraphs up!), but the way she said it does sort of open her up to the criticism of sounding “privileged”, and perhaps rightly so. What is a fascinating academic semi-abstract concept to one person might be existentially earth-shaking on a primal emotional level to another, and it seems like a good idea to always keep that in mind. (I will say that she comes across as a very well-meaning person, and apparently she’s only 22-ish. I probably sounded an awful lot like her when I was her age, and I may sound too much like that at times even today.)

      Finally, a major aspect of the issue that I think isn’t emphasized enough is that when these types of scandals happen, unequivocal denunciation and persecution from the Left runs the risk of driving the person at the center of it in a conservative direction, quite possibly directly into the arms of the alt-right! That’s what appears to have happened with Damore after being suddenly thrust into the spotlight in the wake of the whole Google fiasco. I hope that Shepherd manages to avoid that path, but she does seem to be getting more and more friendly towards Peterson… and she has stated, “I considered myself left-leaning, and I kind of still do, but also… I’ve also been tempted by the idea of like, maybe I should just like, join the right? They’re being so welcoming to me. Yeah I should just join the right.” I hope hearing her say this gives her left-wing attackers some pause.

      *inasmuch as it’s clear what that even means; trans issues are a subject I’ve been a bit shy about discussing but I may lay out my general picture of it in an effortpost soon

      • Adrian says:
        February 12, 2018 at 5:04 am

        On the surface this seems all right (and I came dangerously close to expressing the same attitude a couple of paragraphs up!), but the way she said it does sort of open her up to the criticism of sounding “privileged”, and perhaps rightly so. What is a fascinating academic semi-abstract concept to one person might be existentially earth-shaking on a primal emotional level to another, and it seems like a good idea to always keep that in mind.

        This sounds like the standard privilege argument meant to suppress all opposing opinions: “Oh, sorry, you’re not oppressed enough to weigh in on this discussion, so come back when you agree with me. Check your privilege, by the way!”

        Being “privileged” does not mean you’re wrong, and being “unprivileged” does not mean you’re right – and that’s assuming that the concept of “white/male/whatever privilege” is even valid. Lindsay Shepherd is a woman and a vegetarian, but apparently that doesn’t earn her enough victim points to be allowed to open her mouth on this matter.

        What is a fascinating academic semi-abstract concept to one person might be existentially earth-shaking on a primal emotional level to another, and it seems like a good idea to always keep that in mind.

        Why, and to what effect? For some people, vaccinating children is “existentially earth-shaking on a primal emotional level”, but that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t explain how unreasonable and dangerous anti-vaxxing is.

        • liskantope says:
          February 12, 2018 at 6:24 am

          You seem to have read a lot more into my quoted comment than I intended, bundling it in with the full-blown dogma of people with too many privilege points not being allowed to speak. That’s not what I was saying at all.

          I was making (as a side comment) a “much more minor and subtle criticism” of the tone and diction Shepherd used when talking about her academic interest in hearing Peterson’s take on trans issues. Regardless of the position Shepherd was trying to argue (in this case the meta-position of saying “these issues are interesting and I like to expose myself to all sides” which I’m completely on board with), she could maybe have chosen her words with a bit more sensitivity. There’s a big difference between that and saying she should sit down and shut up.

          • Adrian says:
            February 12, 2018 at 7:33 am

            You seem to have read a lot more into my quoted comment than I intended, bundling it in with the full-blown dogma of people with too many privilege points not being allowed to speak. That’s not what I was saying at all.

            I believe you, and I’m sorry that I misinterpreted your intent.

            I do think, however, that what you wrote comes very close to “she’s privileged and therefore should be very careful not to sound offensive”. It’s very difficult not to offend some oppressed, victimized group out there. Shepherd’s comment (“I like listening to people like Jordan Peterson even if I disagree with him, because I find people like that interesting and their ideas fascinating to ponder, it’s something I really enjoy doing.”) is harmless and well-intentioned in my ears.

            Do we really have to be so careful to avoid even well-intentioned statements, for fear that someone with too thin skin might feel offended? Can we be so careful and still have any kind of reasonable public debate about any controversial topic?

          • The original Mr. X says:
            February 12, 2018 at 8:22 am

            Do we really have to be so careful to avoid even well-intentioned statements, for fear that someone with too thin skin might feel offended? Can we be so careful and still have any kind of reasonable public debate about any controversial topic?

            This sort of thing usually ends up as an isolated demand for extreme rigour. Members of the recognised victim groups can get away with saying all sorts of things because they’re oppressed, but people like Peterson and Shepherd have to frame their statements in the most circumspect and platitudinous way possible, because anything that could be construed as offensive or privileged will be, and will be used as an excuse to ignore them or worse.

            (Not saying that this is what Liskantope is trying to do, but it is how the debate seems to pan out in practice.)

      • Nick says:
        February 13, 2018 at 1:09 pm

        Finally, a major aspect of the issue that I think isn’t emphasized enough is that when these types of scandals happen, unequivocal denunciation and persecution from the Left runs the risk of driving the person at the center of it in a conservative direction, quite possibly directly into the arms of the alt-right! That’s what appears to have happened with Damore after being suddenly thrust into the spotlight in the wake of the whole Google fiasco. I hope that Shepherd manages to avoid that path, but she does seem to be getting more and more friendly towards Peterson… and she has stated, “I considered myself left-leaning, and I kind of still do, but also… I’ve also been tempted by the idea of like, maybe I should just like, join the right? They’re being so welcoming to me. Yeah I should just join the right.” I hope hearing her say this gives her left-wing attackers some pause.

        Thank you thank you thank you for making this point.

        What is a fascinating academic semi-abstract concept to one person might be existentially earth-shaking on a primal emotional level to another, and it seems like a good idea to always keep that in mind.

        This sounds to me like an argument for content warnings. As I understand them, folks like Haidt (and to a lesser extent Peterson) broadly think content warnings, and being able to opt out of potentially very distressing material, is a bad idea, and that folks should instead become stronger so they can face it. What frustrates me about this is that it feels like a giant false dichotomy to me: surely you can encourage trans folks to encounter Blanchard-Bailey or whatever while still providing them content warnings so that they can opt out if they feel they need to. So I agree Shepherd sounds a little privileged there, but at the same time this is totally something that academics and professors should be doing, and more importantly a practice they should be exposing students to, too. If some folks, on some topics, don’t want to subject themselves to that, let them opt out so that we can still actually discuss ideas.

    • Fuge says:
      February 12, 2018 at 7:47 am

      I don’t worry about this, because I think that those kinds of questions really aren’t in the purpose of free and rational inquiry, but cultural warfare.

      1. Not using a pronoun can be valid to a point, but it can also be used to dehumanize a person by denying them the right to their own name. If you refused to call a straight man “he,” that’s really not for any good reason is it?

      2. The two genders thing…look, no offense, but apart from pregnancy and body structure you end up in a huge morass of trying to gender activities and feelings common to both sexes. Strict gender roles are a straight jacket, especially when used against those who transgress them.

      3. Abnormal is a loaded word. Uncommon, maybe, but you are now running into the problem of defining normal as a discrete thing, and why it is good. Chesterton in Eugenics and other Evils said that being healthy is more a relation of different qualities than a state in itself. You could argue the same thing for being normal, which makes labeling abnormal a person is dicey, because they often just have similar qualities to normal people in different relations.

      4. I’m critical religious belief is ‘real’ (not really.) Does that give me carte blanche to argue it in a college class, or freedom from discipline if I don’t shut up about telling the religious members in class they are essentially deluded morons? I think you don’t worry about law as a punishment when you are civil.

      5.Well, tbh this sounds like wanting to be able to explain religious belief or political belief through a personal, pet ideology, like freudianism. Especially since the particular system is a hair short of calling people perverts in practice. Might as well say religious people believe because they get off on being controlled by an authority figure, it’s about as scientific.

      • quanta413 says:
        February 12, 2018 at 11:55 am

        It is mostly socially acceptable to argue for (4) and (5) reasonably or unreasonably in a university as long as the religion in question is Christianity. The “unreasonable” arguments are the price we pay to be able to have “reasonable” arguments. This is a good trade-off overall and should apply to almost every topic that could come up at a University. Exceptions should be made for behavior along the lines of “I am going to pipe bomb X’s house later this week if X doesn’t shut up” not being protected by free speech protections which is already in line with current U.S. law about free speech.

        • LadyJane says:
          February 12, 2018 at 1:25 pm

          As someone who’s spent much of their life in academia, I guarantee you, if any professor ever told a Christian student that their beliefs were objectively false and called them a “deluded moron,” they would be fired in a fraction of a heartbeat. This whole Jordan Peterson debacle would look like a minor scuffle in comparison. I know social conservatives love to think of themselves as oppressed, but religious institutions actually do have a lot more social power than trans people do. If anything like the premise of “God’s Not Dead” actually happened in real life, that university would probably be sued into oblivion.

          And as I’ve already explained ad nauseum throughout this thread, free speech laws only protect people from government censorship. They don’t prevent employers from firing people, they don’t prevent schools from treating certain viewpoints as objectively wrong, and they certainly don’t prevent social backlash and damage to one’s reputation.

          • toastengineer says:
            February 12, 2018 at 2:17 pm

            As someone who’s spent much of their life in academia, I guarantee you, if any professor ever told a Christian student that their beliefs were objectively false and called them a “deluded moron,” they would be fired in a fraction of a heartbeat.

            That goes heavily against my priors. Do you have evidence to back this statement up?

          • The original Mr. X says:
            February 12, 2018 at 2:27 pm

            As someone who’s spent much of their life in academia, I guarantee you, if any professor ever told a Christian student that their beliefs were objectively false and called them a “deluded moron,” they would be fired in a fraction of a heartbeat.

            A professor who calls a student a “deluded moron” (over any belief, not just Christianity) is bullying them, so it’s not surprising they’d get fired. If a professor said that Christianity was false in a less obnoxious way, or presented their lectures in a way that assumed the falsehood of Christianity, they’d be extremely unlikely to suffer any ill consequences.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 12, 2018 at 7:16 pm

            As someone who’s spent much of their life in academia, I guarantee you, if any professor ever told a Christian student that their beliefs were objectively false and called them a “deluded moron,” they would be fired in a fraction of a heartbeat.

            As someone who has spent virtually his entire life in Academia, I can assure you that that is not true. If a professor did that in class and it came to the attention of his dean he might get spoken to, advised not to behave like that. Or he might not, depending on the school, the professor, and the dean. If he was a tenured professor in the U.S. he could not be “fired in a heartbeat” and he probably could not be fired at all.

            If all he did was to say that the views were objectively false and imply that anyone who believed them was deluded, without making a point of being rude to a particular student, there would probably, in most schools, be no consequences for him.

            And as I’ve already explained ad nauseum throughout this thread, free speech laws only protect people from government censorship. They don’t prevent employers from firing people, they don’t prevent schools from treating certain viewpoints as objectively wrong, and they certainly don’t prevent social backlash and damage to one’s reputation.

            I agree. But the particular case that was being discussed occurred in a government school, and free speech laws in the U.S. do limit the degree to which government employers can fire employees for their speech acts. That may not be true in Canada, where the case actually occurred.

          • Bugmaster says:
            February 12, 2018 at 8:24 pm

            FWIW, in my Evolutionary Biology class, the professor literally made a Creationist student cry. He didn’t call her any names, but he didn’t pull any verbal punches, either. To be fair, she did sort of volunteer for the treatment by trying to proselytize in class…

          • Protagoras says:
            February 12, 2018 at 8:38 pm

            That they’d get fired is perhaps an exaggeration, but most professors are not in the habit of antagonizing students, as student complaints and parent complaints are headaches very much to be avoided. On the current topic, I am in philosophy and so know a lot of philosophy professors. Most of them are atheists. Most of the ones I know try to avoid revealing their own religious views in class (and saying someone’s deluded for believing in God would be a bit of a giveaway that one is an atheist). Not all of them, to be sure; I do happen to know Dan Dennett, but I’m inclined to suspect that even he is less aggressive in advocating atheism in his classes than in his books, just because that seems to be understood by everyone to be the way things are done.

            I don’t think that’s a consistent experience with your working model.
