          • Nornagest says:
            February 13, 2018 at 3:10 pm

            One memorable anecdote was taking a 200-level anthropology course where the textbook blandly asserted that Hinduism is a social control mechanism created by the Brahmins to convince the rest of society that they should work toward a better next incarnation rather than having a revolution (comrade).

            “Comrade” is probably exactly right. Anthropology is one of the fields where there’s still a live Marxian tradition — though this means less that Marxian anthropologists are going to be agitating for a communist revolution and more that they’re going to be seeing things through a lens descended from historical materialist ideas.

            It’s not even necessarily a bad lens. I took some archaeology classes in school from a guy that subscribed to it, and found them fairly insightful and surprisingly un-Culture Warry, although its focus on economics and class dynamics to the exclusion of other aspects of culture sometimes struck me as limiting. Guess it’s hard to wage the culture war when everything you’re learning about takes place in the archaic American Southwest before anyone within four thousand miles had seen hide nor hair of a Spaniard, though.

          • Le Maistre Chat says:
            February 13, 2018 at 3:53 pm

            @Nornagest: “Comrade” is probably exactly right. Anthropology is one of the fields where there’s still a live Marxian tradition … It’s not even necessarily a bad lens. I took some archaeology classes in school from a guy that subscribed to it, and found them fairly insightful and surprisingly un-Culture Warry, although its focus on economics and class dynamics to the exclusion of other aspects of culture sometimes struck me as limiting.

            Oh, I know. Historical materialism may or may not be a bad lens, depending on whether the academic is trying to stir up trouble with it. Marvin Harris even used it to defend what Westerners would otherwise consider wacky superstitions about , as the book title goes, Cows, Pigs, Wars and Witches.

          • quaelegit says:
            February 13, 2018 at 4:35 pm

            @Le Maistre Chat

            Thank you for explaining. This whole thread is already quite culture-warry, of course, but that’s when you want to be especially careful to frame for light not heat (which I think you are doing). I can see your point about a double standard.

            @Nornagest

            The one anthropology class I took (on folklore) also didn’t seem very Marxist at all, but then not clear how the two would overlap much — e.g. taking the whole proletariat as a folk group doesn’t make a lot of sense.

          • quanta413 says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:16 pm

            @LadyJane

            I was going to respond saying I’ve been in academia for about a decade now and you’re trying to pull a fast one on me by claiming experience you assume I don’t have… but David Friedman beat to the punch with his multiple decades. Plus the other responses.

            And I was not claiming that religious people are oppressed or anything silly like that (EDIT: referring only to U.S. Christians in U.S. colleges obviously, some religious groups in some places are oppressed). But you can say Christianity is false or that it’s the opiate of the masses or read some passages from Richard Dawkins and it will be totally ok, and your university bosses aren’t going to give you a talking to. The rules that lead to this outcome are good general rules and no new exceptions are currently needed.

            You are talking about freedom of speech laws, but I am talking about Freedom of Speech. Freedom of Speech is much more important than just as a government rule. The idea for it didn’t fall from the heavens with the first amendment. It’s important as a cultural ideal for fostering debate in a liberal society.

            And just so we’re totally clear, I am an atheist and I’m fine referring to people as “ornate buildings” if they really feel strongly enough about it.

          • Chevalier Mal Fet says:
            February 14, 2018 at 5:41 am

            As a datapoint, in my own time college I had a professor who was, er, obviously not impressed with Christianity’s truth claims – this was ten years ago now, so I can’t give you an exact quote, but many times in class he outright stated or heavily implied that Christianity was obviously false and anyone who still held to it was obviously deluded. He never suffered any consequences.

            Nor should he have, I think. I’m a believing Christian, but I never particularly minded his statements, because he was a brilliant professor (although not an ideal teacher at all). Getting offended over someone’s acerbic personality and trying to shut him down would have cost the university one of its better minds.

      • DavidFriedman says:
        February 12, 2018 at 7:04 pm

        At a slight tangent, consider an older but somewhat analogous issue.

        Catholics do not believe in divorce. Nelson Rockefeller, governor of New York, got divorced and remarried. Is a believing Catholic required to refer to his second wife as “Mrs. Rockefeller” even though he doesn’t believe she is? As his wife?

        • Brad says:
          February 12, 2018 at 7:11 pm

          It’d be extremely rude to do otherwise. Governments ought not (and in the US may not) punish anyone for this extreme rudeness, but it is entirely right and proper that such people be subjected to severe private sanctions for their rudeness.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 12, 2018 at 7:21 pm

            I strongly disagree. It would, in most circumstances, be rude to make a point of the fact that she was, from the speaker’s point of view, living in sin. But to refer to her as Mrs. Rockefeller would be to endorse a view the Catholic speaker did not hold; anyone who tried to pressure someone in that situation to do so would be the one who was being extremely rude.

            Do you consider it rude to refrain from telling a lie?

          • Brad says:
            February 12, 2018 at 7:39 pm

            Rudeness and the definition of words are matters of social consensus. By the socially accepted definition of ‘lie’ it is not one to use words and usages as they are socially defined even if those definitions conflict with some sort of internal idiosyncratic definitions.

            Mrs. Rockerfeller was Mrs. Rockerfeller and Mr. Rockerfeller’s wife by the lights of the society that speaker was living in. If that society’s definitions and values were so totally incompatible with the speaker’s private metaphysics he was unable to bear living in it or fulfilling his duties as a polite member of that society, he was entitled to withdraw from it and find a society more suited to his own values. Perhaps in Vatican City. He was also entitled to try to convince the other members of that society that his definition was better and ought to be adopted.

            But until and unless he convinced them, and if he chose to stay and chose to deliberately transgress the socially constructed rules of behavior of the society he was living in then the social consequences that flowed from those transgressions were entirely deserved.

            This idea that one is entitled to be shockingly rude because he believes something strongly and no one else is entitled to treat him poorly for having been shockingly rude is nonsense. An (alleged) strongly held belief is not a plenary license to violate social norms. If you feel so strongly than bear the consequences of insisting on your beliefs over those of everyone else.

          • Wrong Species says:
            February 12, 2018 at 8:15 pm

            Rudeness is an odd way to frame a difference in moral beliefs. You’re saying that they should implicitly endorse a belief they vehemently disagree with for the sake of politeness. I’m too tired to think of an example right now but that kind of thing could be used against your beliefs as well.

          • Brad says:
            February 12, 2018 at 9:03 pm

            I think rudenesss is quite an appropriate framework. There’s a notion among those of a certain type of personality, prevalent but my no means exclusive to ’round here, that claims that speaking Truth is the ultimate good. To a certain extent that’s fine, it’s you’re right to follow your Truth down a road that leads you to break taboos, violate norms, and offend people. But that very same right applies equally to the rest of us. We can decide to (privately) sanction you.

            I don’t support a set of norms that says that you can be rude to me because that’s where your Truth leads you, but I am not allowed to respond to such rudeness because I have to respect the sacredness of your following your deeply held beliefs.

            If you come knocking on my door at 8AM in the morning to tell I’m a sinner and I’d better repent, you’ve been very rude to me and I’m going to treat you accordingly. I don’t especially care if you think God wanted you to knock on my door. That’s not relevant to me. The same thing if you ostentatiously refuse to address my mother as Mrs. So-and-so because you think God doesn’t want her to be addressed that way.

            Like I said, I wouldn’t excuse religiously motivated rudeness. But at least it is a closer case. After all we excuse even murder under the doctrine of deific decree. But the case of pronouns is so much weaker. It is rudeness based in nothing more than an insistence on using private prescriptivist definitions of words. There is nothing more obviously socially constructed than words. How can it possibly be a ‘lie’, the avoidance of which purportedly justifies rudeness, to use a word in comporting with its descriptivist definition? Is it a lie to use gauntlet to mean “a form of punishment in which people armed with sticks or other weapons arrange themselves in two lines and beat a person forced to run between them”?

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:43 am

            If you come knocking on my door at 8AM in the morning to tell I’m a sinner and I’d better repent, you’ve been very rude to me and I’m going to treat you accordingly.

            I suggest that the fact that you have to convert my example, where someone fails to describe a person in a way he believes to be false, into that one, is some evidence that you are arguing with a bad conscience–that the case I gave doesn’t feel rude to you, so you have to convert it into one that does.

            Consider the case of a couple who are living together without marriage in a society with traditional views of the subject. Making a point of telling them that they are living in sin would in most circumstances be rude. That doesn’t mean that failing to describe a man’s lover as his wife or a woman’s lover as her husband is rude.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 4:54 am

            Brad –

            They aren’t the only ones being linguistic prescriptivists here.

            The entire goddamn argument is about what words mean, hidden in a moralistic argument based on the idea that one side is emotionally hurt when words aren’t used in the specifically prescribed way that they understand them.

            But, uh, only one set of prescriptivists here is insisting everybody else use their personal prescriptivist definitions of words.

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 5:04 am

            @DavidFriedman
            If you keep reading you’ll find your example repeated. But thanks for telling me what I really think, I guess.

            Are you familiar with the case of Plaid Cymru legislator expelled from Wales’ devolved parliament after referring in a speech to “Mrs. Windsor”? Do you consider that behavior perfectly fine and the expulsion and pressure to refer instead to Queen Elizabeth or Her Majesty unfair?

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 5:30 am

            @Thegnskald

            The entire goddamn argument is about what words mean, hidden in a moralistic argument based on the idea that one side is emotionally hurt when words aren’t used in the specifically prescribed way that they understand them.

            I’d say it isn’t really about what words mean, since no one is going out and citing corpuses. But I wholly agree that the moralistic argument is a shell that doesn’t make much sense. I don’t see what the deep moral question is supposed to be on the anti-accommodation side. The fundamental disagreement seems to be more aesthetic than anything else.

            I meant what I said about rudeness being socially constructed. That’s what the dumb jokes about “I identify as Napoleon” miss. A single individual can’t unilaterally create a norm like that. Look at DF’s latest hypo “Consider the case of a couple who are living together without marriage in a society with traditional views of the subject.” In most contexts, in that society it probably wouldn’t be rude to refuse to refer to the lover as a wife, but in some bohemian subculture within that society it might be.

            If you want to disagree about what the prevailing politeness norms of particular venues actually are, I suppose those are thousands of little debates we could have. But I’m not sure there’d be much of a point. What I took away from the “Mrs. Rockefeller” question was a situation where it is concededly the overwhelming social norm to refer to her that way (see LadyJane’s post below which matches my experiences) and the question is whether private disagreement was sufficient to turn rudeness into non-rudeness in that circumstance.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 5:41 am

            Brad –

            It is not a norm at a societal level, however, it is a norm in specific subsections of society.

            If we are falling back on the “social norm” argument, then we are left with a problem, because we have two competing social norms here. Worse, one of the norms is extremely new, and a huge part of the argument is trying to get the remaining hold-outs to buy into the new norm.

            The substantive issue being, I am not certain the hold-outs don’t outnumber the people who have already agreed to it.

            So it isn’t at all clear that we can even say it is rude, in this social sense; at best we can say it is rude in certain social situations in which everybody is agreed.

          • Aapje says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:13 am

            In general, it seems doubtful whether an objective standard can even exist. It seems that pretty much everyone believes that there are norms that should be universally enforced & norms on which subcultures may deviate. Unfortunately, language is often used (unconsciously) as a weapon, rather than reasonably.

            For example, you see people get angry over ‘intolerance,’ who themselves are clearly intolerant of many things. You see people get angry over ‘rudeness’, who themselves defend doing what some other consider very rude. Etc.

            So you have many people who claim that their position is correct because it is more consistent with a value in some way, even though this value has to be balanced with other values, something which is far from trivial.

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:19 am

            @Thegnskald
            I don’t find much to disagree with in there. But think about what that means in the larger picture. When we a society were in the transition from Negro to African-American were those trying to bring about the tabooing of the former and adoption of the latter fairly attacked with reference to gulags and Orwell? Was freedom of conscience frequently invoked? Did people claim they were being forced to lie by using the term African-American? And today, would you (socially) give a pass to someone using the term Negros if he offered some kind of explanation about how in his internal system of beliefs Negro is the one True referent?

            Again, I’m not saying you are wrong about the empirical question of where we are on a society wide level. You may well be right. But in certain places, like say Canadian college campuses, there are different prevailing norms. I don’t think personal aesthetics are a good reason to transgress (possibly local) norms. People are free to disagree and go ahead and transgress those norms, but then they will be subject to social sanctions. And I don’t think those meting out those social sanctions are doing anything wrong. Without social sanctions we can’t have norms and all-in-all norms are pretty important.

          • Wrong Species says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:28 am

            @Brad

            How can it possibly be a ‘lie’, the avoidance of which purportedly justifies rudeness, to use a word in comporting with its descriptivist definition?

            Why do transgendered people get offended when someone refers to them by the wrong pronoun? It’s not just the word that’s relevant, it’s the meaning that the word use implies. For this hypothetical Catholic, calling this woman “Mrs. Rockefeller” isn’t just an aesthetic issue. It’s an implicit approval of the prevailing secular norms on divorce. I think what you’re trying to do is disentangle politeness from ethics but I don’t think you can. Whatever you think is rude overlaps considerably with your ethical beliefs. We could tell this person that they’re beliefs are wrong so they should shut up, but it doesn’t really make much sense to say that they may or may not be wrong in their ethical beliefs but it doesn’t matter either way with regard to the issue.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:45 am

            Brad –

            I think “African-American” is stupid and kind of racist in a way that a referent to skin color isn’t, and have always preferred “black” if I absolutely have to refer to race.

            But yes, I give people exactly that pass, if, say, they are a Mexican immigrant, and are just using their native word for “black” instead of trying to be offensive.

            It is the latter part that is pertinent, not the former.

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:55 am

            @Thegnskald

            But yes, I give people exactly that pass, if, say, they are a Mexican immigrant, and are just using their native word for “black” instead of trying to be offensive.

            It is the latter part that is pertinent, not the former.

            Once you are aware of the norm and double down, you may not intend to be offensive but you know you are being offensive and don’t care. That amounts to the same thing.

            It’s like the people that go around finding a way to work niggardly into the conversation. “You’re not wrong, Walter …”

          • Matt M says:
            February 13, 2018 at 7:00 am

            Once you are aware of the norm and double down, you may not intend to be offensive but you know you are being offensive and don’t care. That amounts to the same thing.

            It is not the same thing. It’s essentially neutral. Neither party has the right to dictate the manner of speech, or the feelings of the other.

            Yeah, there’s a sense in which someone might choose to be nice and stop saying things that others find offensive. Of course, I could just as easily suggest the problem can be solved by the aggrieved party simply deciding to stop being offended by words that are not intended to cause offense.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 7:08 am

            Brad –

            I see.

            So when middle-class women stood up against the social norms of their time in order to go to work, they were just being offensive?

            And likewise for anti-racism advocates?

            People ignoring social norms in favor of principles is heroic when they successfully change the social norms, and antisocial when they fail. But it is impossible to know in advance which category you belong in, or in which category future society will put you, or the people you criticize, in. Which means you advocate against opposing the prevailing social norms.

            Which I will grant is the least risky approach, but which I must remind you would not have resulted in the society you live in, or the norms you currently approve of.

            Also, social norms aren’t. Everybody follows them because they expect everyone else to follow them, but set up a safe space to violate them, like a card game that is racist and sexist for you, and the norms vanish. Nobody actually believes in the things, they are just terrified everybody else does, and most people spend their entire lives obsessing over what other people think of them.

            And when you realize this, when you realize that the only people who pay attention to the norms other people are violating are those who don’t care what norms they themselves violate – being that the people who are worried about violating norms are too worried about violating norms to pay attention to other people – the whole edifice comes crashing down in a puff of “Holy shit this is a system run by sociopathic assholes for their own benefit”.

            (Seriously. Look around at the people enforcing the social norms.)

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 7:43 am

            @Thegnskald
            It seems to me you want to eat your cake and have it too. It rather reminds me of people that think that “I was engaging in civil disobedience” ought to be a get out of jail free card. The norm breakers that are successful are heroic exactly because they sacrificed for what they believed in. That they were willing to make those sacrifices was part of what gave force to their arguments.

            Furthermore, there’s nothing at all that’s inherently noble about breaking norms or disobeying civil authority. The object level is once again absolutely critical here.

            Maybe in five years JP will be seen as a heroic leader in the backlash against political correctness. And maybe he’ll look back and think that the years of sitting through faculty meetings while his colleagues condemned him was all worth it. But I won’t criticize those colleagues, both because I mostly agree with them on the object level and because I see absolutely nothing wrong with social sanctions as a tool for norm enforcement at the meta level.

            In terms of your argument that there aren’t *really* any social norms, I disagree. First, I don’t think the kind of peer-pressure mediated edgelord spiral you are describing is as common as you are claiming and second, I reject the idea that the face shown in poker game with your buddies is somehow more authentic than the face shown when alone with a spouse, or at work, or sitting at a family dinner. I don’t even think “more authentic” is an especially useful concept. The guy that tells his buddies he wants to fuck bitches and writes saccharine love letters to his girlfriend is the kind of guy who tells his buddies he wants to fuck bitches and writes saccharine love letters to his girlfriend. One isn’t the ‘true him’ and the other a lie. They are both him.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 8:09 am

            I want to have my cake and eat it too?

            In case you haven’t picked this up, I am not arguing for a situational use of social norms as a guide to good behavior. I am arguing against the use of social norms as a guide to good behavior, period. I am a leftist; manners and politeness favor the status quo. That’s part of our deal. When did you become The Man?

            And I will sum up the reason with some rhetorical questions I will assume the answer to.

            Have you ever challenged somebody in-person over the violation of a social norm?

            You know that queasy feeling as you consider doing it? That is your mind yelling at you because you are about to violate a social norm. It is a social faux pax to bring up somebody else’s faux pax; it is against social norms to challenge somebody for violating social norms.

            Literally the only people who challenge people on social norms are people who violate social norms, because it is a violation of social norms to do so.

            Think about that for a moment. It is rude to call somebody else rude.

            But nobody is actually consciously aware of this dynamic; we are all a little relieved when a situation requires violating the rules, and somebody else does so. The racist guy yelling at the elderly black woman produces a contradiction in social norms – everybody is expected to speak up, while simultaneously everybody is forbidden from doing so. “Nonconfrontational” in British-descended cultures is part of the social norm.

            So yeah, seriously. Social norms are fucking garbage, because at this point they get decided by whoever ignores them. Which is why the cosmopolitan, manner-centric circles are all full of sociopathic assholes.

            Christ. I leave Leftism for a little while and come back to discover all the punks are wearing business suits.

            ETA: And this is a bit of a metapoint, but gender norms are themselves social norms. Doubly fuck that shit.

          • A Definite Beta Guy says:
            February 13, 2018 at 8:13 am

            Rudeness is an odd way to frame a difference in moral beliefs. You’re saying that they should implicitly endorse a belief they vehemently disagree with for the sake of politeness. I’m too tired to think of an example right now but that kind of thing could be used against your beliefs as well.

            They should not be required to implicitly endorse any beliefs. To do so is in itself rude. Like, the polite thing to do is not to force a believing Catholic into a position where they must refer to a second wife as “Mrs. Rockefeller.” Forcing people to choose between a social transgression and a deeply-held principle is rude.

            But, yeah, if you’re making a point to show that you disapprove of Rockefeller’s second wife, you’re being rude. Same if you’re trying to make a point that a devout Catholic doesn’t really believe your second wife is actually your wife. Same if you are trying to continually force Jordan Peterson to refer to Caitlyn Jenner as a beautiful brave woman.

            Politeness and kindness obviously require making space and accommodations for those with minority beliefs.

            There’s also the question of context. If you are writing a newspaper column or a blog post explaining why you don’t think Mrs. Rockefeller is really Mrs. Rockefeller, whatever. If you bring that shit to my Thanksgiving table, someone is going to sock you in the jaw. Don’t bring it to my Thanksgiving table, thankyouverymuch.

            Think about that for a moment. It is rude to call somebody else rude.

            Well, yeah. That’s why we have passive-aggressiveness and social ostracism. People who are rude are not invited to cool parties and get lots of sarcasm thrown their way.

          • The Nybbler says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:01 am

            You know that queasy feeling as you consider doing it? That is your mind yelling at you because you are about to violate a social norm. It is a social faux pax to bring up somebody else’s faux pax; it is against social norms to challenge somebody for violating social norms.

            Whether it is OK to call out a violation of social norms depends on a status relationship between the objector and the violator. I don’t call it a hierarchy because I think it is not strictly hierarchical and probably not even coherent. In general a woman in her late middle age or older may call out a violation on any adult. An older man may call out a violation by a younger man, but if the younger man is black the older man must be black also. No one unrelated may call out a violation by a child (no, not even to the parent). All sorts of other rules.

          • The original Mr. X says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:01 am

            The norm breakers that are successful are heroic exactly because they sacrificed for what they believed in. That they were willing to make those sacrifices was part of what gave force to their arguments.

            So if I’m willing to suffer social sanctions rather than pretend that Mr. Rockefeller’s adulterous relationship is a real marriage, that makes me heroic and gives force to my arguments on the indissolubility of marriage? Or does this line of reasoning only apply to beliefs you agree with?

          • The original Mr. X says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:03 am

            @ Thegnskald:

            When did you become The Man?

            At a guess, approximately 0.5 milliseconds after his views became culturally dominant.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:52 am

            “So if I’m willing to suffer social sanctions rather than pretend that Mr. Rockefeller’s adulterous relationship is a real marriage, that makes me heroic and gives force to my arguments on the indissolubility of marriage?”

            Heroic? No, simply because I disagree with you on the object level, and courageous heroism versus courageous villainy is really a matter of perspective. Brave? Yes, absolutely. But I don’t see much courage in arguing that there shouldn’t be any social consequences to begin with.

            If you really believe that trans women are just delusional cis men, and you feel so strongly about it that you absolutely refuse to refer to a trans woman by female or even neutral pronouns under any circumstances, and you’re actually willing to get expelled or fired or socially ostracized for it, rather than just complaining on the internet that it’s not something that should get you expelled/fired/ostracized… well, I can respect the courage in that, even if I find your actual views both objectively wrong from an empirical perspective and morally repulsive. (Though I rather cynically suspect that most of the people arguing against me here wouldn’t actually have that courage in real life, and would only deliberately misgender trans people in social situations where they felt like they could safely get away with it without suffering any negative consequences.)

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 11:32 am

            Though I rather cynically suspect that most of the people arguing against me here wouldn’t actually have that courage in real life, and would only deliberately misgender trans people in social situations where they felt like they could safely get away with it without suffering any negative consequences.

            Notice how you slide from someone choosing not to use the pronoun he considers false to “deliberately misgender trans people in social situations.”

            If you believe your position, why do you insist on putting the argument in terms of people who are trying to be rude? Why isn’t it “would have the courage to refrain from using gendered pronouns when doing so would require them to either misrepresent their own views or offend someone else, even if the use of a gendered pronoun would otherwise be natural in the context of what they are saying”?

            That’s the obvious description of how those of us who reject your position and prefer not to be rude if they can reasonably avoid it behave. It doesn’t seem to be how you want us to behave.

            To apply your approach in the other direction, do you really have the courage to say to someone who has been avoiding the use of gendered pronouns in such a situation “Say ‘her’ when referring to her, damn you–what are you, a transphobe?”

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 11:57 am

            @Thegnskald

            I am arguing against the use of social norms as a guide to good behavior, period. I am a leftist; manners and politeness favor the status quo. That’s part of our deal. When did you become The Man?

            I’ve never been a leftist in that sense. I’m neither a radical nor a reactionary. I think things are pretty good (even despite Donald Trump) and are likely to get better in the near and medium term. I have no interest in revolution, and getting rid of all social norms certainly qualifies as that. I’m happy that rigid gender norms are fading, but as far as I’m concerned that don’t need to disappear all at once, yesterday. Slow and steady progress works for me.

            The reason I am a “leftist” around here is because the post frequency adjusted median poster when it comes to social issues is way way out to the right. Or at least it looks a lot that way because it is natural to categorize people by which outgroups they constantly choose to attack.

          • Thegnskald says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:13 pm

            Brad –

            That gives you a flawed perspective of who believes what. Our most vicious enemies tend to be those who were almost our allies.

          • A Definite Beta Guy says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:16 pm

            Man, skepticism about transgender rights is not a fringe position.

            http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2017/11/08/transgender-issues-divide-republicans-and-democrats/

            The majority of Americans apparently don’t think transgender is even a thing. That’s almost true even among Millennials. It’s actually an issue that my Millennial leftist friends HAVE noticed: they thought they were super-progressive because they supported gay marriage, then the Zennials came in with transgender rights, and they had to reconsider how progressive they really were.

            I guess the specific case of bringing it up at a party might be rightist or whatever, but that’s more a question of “what do you think is polite social behavior” rather than ideology, IMO.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:46 pm

            @DavidFriedman: If someone was simply using gender-neutral pronouns, or avoiding the use of pronouns altogether, I wouldn’t confront them about it. I wouldn’t even have any real problem with it per se, though I would find it highly conspicuous. I would also wonder if it meant they had a problem with trans people in general, and while I wouldn’t assume bad faith right off the bat, I’d be a little wary around them, at least initially.

            If someone misgendered me or another trans person I knew, I would politely correct them. After that, if they made an effort to use the correct pronouns (or neutral pronouns, or no pronouns), but still slipped up from time to time, I would ignore the periodic slip-ups. If it became too frequent, I would correct them again, still politely but a little more firmly.

            If they continued to deliberately and exclusively use the wrong pronouns even after being corrected, I would aggressively confront them about it. If they still continued after that, I would stop associating with them altogether.

            If that wasn’t an option (for instance, if they were a classmate or a student or a co-worker, or a close friend of a close friend), I would make an appeal to our teacher/dean/boss/mutual friend to either force them to change their behavior or stop forcing me to be around them. If the person in question was the teacher/dean/boss, I would appeal to their higher-ups. If that didn’t work or wasn’t an option, and I had no other recourse to their harassment, I would strongly consider taking legal action against them.

          • Vorkon says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:50 pm

            When we a society were in the transition from Negro to African-American were those trying to bring about the tabooing of the former and adoption of the latter fairly attacked with reference to gulags and Orwell?

            This analogy really doesn’t work very well, because unlike in the misgendering or “Mrs. Rockefeller” examples, the two social norms aren’t at odds with each other. Someone can be BOTH a “Negro” (i.e. a person with dark skin) and an “African American” (i.e. an American of African descent) with no contradiction between the two. Asking someone who used to say “Negro” to say “African American” instead is not asking this person to lie, or to specifically and publically disavow their belief in the superiority of the previous social norm in order to adopt the new one.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 2:59 pm

            If someone was simply using gender-neutral pronouns

            Unfortunately, English doesn’t have a set of gender neutral pronouns. “It” is neuter, not gender neutral, and likely to be taken as an insult. There are some circumstances in which I can use “one” as a stand-in for a pronoun, but it’s usually clumsy. A lot of people use “they” as a neuter singular, but that offends my ear for reasons having to do with number not gender.

            Usually the most practical solution is to use the person’s name instead of using pronouns.

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 3:23 pm

            @DavidFriedman: Fair enough. In situations where I don’t know someone’s preferred gender pronouns and can’t make a solid guess based on their appearance and presentation, I’ll mostly refer to them by name or use terms like “that one,” and use the singular “they/their” if I use any pronouns at all.

        • LadyJane says:
          February 12, 2018 at 8:18 pm

          “Is a believing Catholic required to refer to his second wife as “Mrs. Rockefeller” even though he doesn’t believe she is?”

          Yes? Not required by law, obviously. But by social norms? Absolutely. I’m genuinely surprised you even brought up an example like this, the answer seems blatantly obvious to me. No offense, but that seems like something an alien with no understanding of human social dynamics would ask.

          I grew up in a Catholic household and spent 12 years in Catholic school, and I’ve never met a Catholic who refused to refer to remarried people by their chosen surname. Even the Catholic priests I’ve known wouldn’t do that.

          • Wrong Species says:
            February 13, 2018 at 6:46 am

            It’s funny that you compare Friedman to an alien for asking this question when the guy below seems to disagree with you. It turns out what is “obvious” is not always obvious. Who knew?

          • LadyJane says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:25 am

            The poster below said it would be “rude, but not a lie,” which I would agree with. Whereas Friedman’s position seemed to be “it’s not rude because it’s not a lie,” or at least “being rude is justified in this particular case because it’s not a lie.”

            I am not debating whether Mrs. Rockefeller’s marriage and surname are valid from a Catholic point of view. That’s irrelevant to me, but for the sake of argument, let’s assume that Friedman is correct and her marriage isn’t valid. I’m debating whether it would be socially acceptable for a Catholic to refuse to call her by her chosen surname because of it. Friedman said it would, I said it wouldn’t, and Anonymous below merely clarified some details about the example itself without taking a strong stance either way.

          • Anonymous says:
            February 13, 2018 at 9:33 am

            @LadyJane

            FWIW, I think it’s morally unacceptable to say something you don’t believe true as if it is. It may be permissible to simply avoid the issue to prevent unnecessary hard feelings.

          • Wrong Species says:
            February 13, 2018 at 11:32 am

            Anonymous just unambiguously disagreed with you, proving my point. You shouldn’t go around accusing people of not understanding social norms just because they ask a question about it. It’s ironic that you’re taking a stand against rudeness, but you do so by being rude to David Friedman, when there was no plausible justification compelling you to be rude.

          • albatross11 says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:17 pm

            To what extent are we really talking about questions of courtesy or right and wrong w.r.t. word choices, and to what extent are we talking about power?

        • Anonymous says:
          February 13, 2018 at 1:51 am

          Catholics do not believe in divorce.

          That’s not true. Divorce for Catholics is possible via the Petrine and Pauline privileges.

          Divorce is more accurately *forbidden* to Catholics, and absent grounds as the above, the Church cannot dissolve a valid sacramental marriage.

          Nelson Rockefeller, governor of New York, got divorced and remarried. Is a believing Catholic required to refer to his second wife as “Mrs. Rockefeller” even though he doesn’t believe she is? As his wife?

          Depends. Is Rockefeller (nominally) Catholic? Was his marriage to his former wife a valid sacramental marriage (not annulled)?

          If so, then this woman is his adulterous mistress, and his previous woman is still his wife. It would be rude, but not a lie, to refer to them as such. It would be a lie to refer to the new woman as his wife.

          If his marriage was annulled, or was never made sacramental, the previous marriage never existed except as an informal relationship as far as the Catholic Church is concerned.

          If he’s not Catholic, then whatever rules are used by his civil/pagan/heretic denomination apply.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            February 13, 2018 at 11:47 am

            Is Rockefeller (nominally) Catholic? Was his marriage to his former wife a valid sacramental marriage (not annulled)?

            I don’t think he was Catholic, so my example was poorly chosen.

            But we can ask the same questions in a hypothetical involving someone who was a Catholic and did get a divorce and remarriage.

          • Anonymous says:
            February 13, 2018 at 1:23 pm

            He’s not a very good Catholic, then, and probably deserves every bit of social opprobrium coming to him. I believe “scandal” is the word here.

        • SamChevre says:
          February 13, 2018 at 3:20 pm

          My mother (Mennonite, not Catholic, but just as conservative on divorce) would have refused to put them in the same bedroom if they came to visit. You may feel free to imagine how well her father took it when she refused to treat the woman he married after divorcing her mother as his wife.

        • Nick says:
          February 13, 2018 at 3:42 pm

          I don’t think I or another Catholic should ever be required to refer to his second wife as “Mrs. Rockefeller,” but Brad is right that most alternatives, to her face, would be extremely rude. But as with the transgender example, I don’t think calling her that means I’m actually affirming it’s a valid marriage—it is, for instance, her legal name. Now, supposing that she heard me call her that, and knew I was Catholic, and asked if I really thought she was married to Mr. Rockefeller, then unless I can avoid the question I’d have to say that no, I don’t think so, and I think it would take some grave circumstances to permissibly engage in such question dodging there anyway. If she takes issue with that, too bad for her.

          Peterson talks a lot about “ceding the linguistic territory” in things like this, but personally, I don’t see a problem with “ceding” this territory, so long as I can make clear that I’m granting such terms for the sake of conversation or politeness, and they aren’t reflecting of my beliefs on the matter.

          • Anonymous says:
            February 14, 2018 at 3:34 am

            FWIW, I don’t consider all rudeness always wrong. There’s something to be said of social pressure to behave in a way that doesn’t trigger rudeness from your coreligionists.

    • S_J says:
      February 12, 2018 at 8:14 am

      Does Canadian law have the concept of “chilling effect” on a right?

      In some circles of American law, the phrase “chilling effect on the exercise of a right” is turned into a strong need to have a court remove the chilling effect by edit.

      The scenario outlined looks like it has a chilling effect, even if one of the Professors eventually wrote a letter of apology.

    • dndnrsn says:
      February 12, 2018 at 9:09 am

      @Aapje

      She’s a grad student. Peterson is a tenured professor. They’re just trying to find something to say to soothe their conscience more than outright admitting “you’re just a TA and we’ll throw you under the bus in a heartbeat if it makes our lives earlier”. Peterson is a tenured prof.

    • Nabil ad Dajjal says:
      February 13, 2018 at 12:39 pm

      Meta-level tangent related to the pronoun flamewar above.

      A lot of people are arguing that under the prevailing social norms it is extremely rude, to the point of constuting harassment, to “misgender” someone by not using the pronoun which matches their professed gender identity. But this social norm only prevailed within the last decade as the result of a top-down push by the media and federal government with essentially no public debate. If someone had fallen into a coma in 2008 and woke up today, they would have full knowledge of all of our social norms except this one.

      So the question is, who determines the social norms? Is it just whoever has the whip-hand at the moment, so in another ten years we could see an equally sudden reversal on e.g. Ms. versus Miss/Mrs.? Or is there some authority beyond naked force which we can appeal to in our society?

      • Brad says:
        February 13, 2018 at 12:56 pm

        I don’t see how federal government is involved in this. Nor do I understand the reference to naked force, where is this force coming from?

        To answer your question, social norms are determined by all of us. There is no whip hand.

        While I agree that someone that had gone into a coma in 2008 would be very unlikely to be familiar enough with the norm to instantly “get it” if told that someone’s preferred pronouns are she and her, but I do think someone with a particular set of meta-norms about respect and self identification going into that coma would pretty quickly see what was going on and adopt the new norm without much fuss.

        Finally, I don’t think anyone is claiming that the new norm is universal and it is certainly possible it will grow weaker rather than stronger over the next ten years. That’s up to all of us. I personally wouldn’t bet that way.

        • Nabil ad Dajjal says:
          February 13, 2018 at 1:28 pm

          I don’t see how federal government is involved in this. Nor do I understand the reference to naked force, where is this force coming from?

          The OP was, in part, about how college rules against misgendering here are explicitly grounded in Title IX reasoning. I would be very surprised if this push had succeeded with a less cooperative civil service and judiciary.

          You’re familiar with the force, because you like to mock the idea of chilling effects here. Corporate HR departments and college administrations have their ears to the ground trying to anticipate what policies won’t get them sued. If the government moves one step to the left they take two steps just to be safe. And so when Joe Schmo gets fired or expelled for saying something politically incorrect people like you can smugly say “the first amendment only refers to government action. I thought you liked the market?”

          This isn’t something particularly complex or difficult to understand. If the Trump administration was sending Dear Colleague letters out about admitting illegal immigrants I’m sure that you wouldn’t have trouble understanding that the threat of lawsuits to deny someone employment or education constitutes force.

          To answer your question, social norms are determined by all of us. There is no whip hand.

          That would be much more plausible if opinion polls didn’t show the public split 50:50, with much of that support coming after the norm was established.

          Obviously the plurality of the country “on the right side of history” had more of a say than the majority who were on the other side. They command, we obey: sounds like a holding the whip to me.

          • Brad says:
            February 13, 2018 at 1:44 pm

            The OP was, in part, about how college rules against misgendering here are explicitly grounded in Title IX reasoning. I would be very surprised if this push had succeeded with a less cooperative civil service and judiciary.

            The OP talks about a bill in Canada and an incident where administrators at a Canadian university interpreted that law. How in the world is a letter sent by the U.S. department of education to US universities regarding its preferred interpretation of a U.S. law as it relates sexual assault disciplinary hearings law relevant whatsoever to a Canadian law and/or an incident involving misgendering at a Canadian university and/or social norms about pronoun usage? And what the heck is “Title IX reasoning” even supposed to mean in the first place?

            And you thought that this connection not only exists in the first place, but is so obvious that an offhand reference to a top down push by the federal government against misgendering would clearly be understood as referring to the dear colleague letter? How bizarre. Like something out of The Prague Cemetery.

          • Nabil ad Dajjal says:
            February 13, 2018 at 1:56 pm

            You can go back to the OP, it’s still there. It explicitly connects the current events in Canada to our troubles with Title IX.

            Like something out of The Prague Cemetery.

            That is an incredibly obscure reference. I had to look it up just to get that you’re comparing me to a fictional conspiracy theorist, which makes it a fairly ineffective insult.

            Anyway I probably shouldn’t have used shorthand. I assumed that since this topic has been done to death everyone is familiar with the events.

      • DavidFriedman says:
        February 13, 2018 at 3:15 pm

        A different tangent from the pronoun discussion …

        In the SCA, people adopt a persona–an imaginary person from someplace in period history. They tend to dress as that persona, sometimes do other things based on their persona. My SCA persona is a North African Muslim, so at SCA events I don’t drink alcohol or eat pork.

        Some people say they have multiple personas. Very rarely, it’s true. In most cases, they have no persona, just multiple names and sets of clothing, all being worn by the same (modern) person. The simplest evidence that they do not have multiple personas is that if you know one of them, the other will treat you as someone he already knows.

        This feels to me like the same sort of issue. What you are is not determined by what you say you are. If I declare that I am six feet tall, I still can’t get things off high shelves without standing on something. If you say you are a 10th c. Norseman today and a 15th c. Italian tomorrow but act as the same person both days, you shouldn’t expect other people to take seriously the idea that they are different.

        Similarly, if you decide you are a woman despite being physically male and continuing to act and look in a way that signals male, you are not entitled to demand that other people pretend to see you as female. One shouldn’t go out of one’s way to point out the conflict, in either case, but one has no obligation to pretend to what one does not believe.

        That’s a common pattern in lots of other contexts. If I try to sing along with “Happy Birthday,” observers should probably not make a point of the fact that I can’t carry a tune, but they have no obligation to pretend that I can.

        • Matt M says:
          February 13, 2018 at 3:28 pm

          Similarly, if you decide you are a woman despite being physically male and continuing to act and look in a way that signals male, you are not entitled to demand that other people pretend to see you as female. One shouldn’t go out of one’s way to point out the conflict, in either case, but one has no obligation to pretend to what one does not believe.

          Well said. This is basically what I believe as well. I’d distinguish between groups:

          1. Those who are passing so well that I don’t even realize they aren’t the gender they identify as – In this case there is no problem, as I’ll never know anything abnormal is going on

          2. Those who are making a clear effort to pass, but are still in some ways visibly their biological gender – In this case, they are making an effort, and I am likely to reciprocate by making an effort to think of them and refer to them as their chosen gender

          3. Those who are making little/no effort to pass – In this case, if they aren’t making an effort, why should I. If you look like a dude in a dress and you aren’t even trying not to look like a dude in a dress, then I’m going to call you and treat you like a dude in a dress.

          This only seems fair.

      • liskantope says:
        February 14, 2018 at 2:26 am

        If someone had fallen into a coma in 2008 and woke up today, they would have full knowledge of all of our social norms except this one.

        Actually, I quite possibly would have known, because I happened to know a genderfluid person just before 2008 who introduced me to that norm. Which (among other things) leads me to suspect that there is a different explanation at hand for the sudden reversal: trans people were (and still are, outside of media attention) a very small and fairly invisible minority, and even though this norm was pushed in much of the trans community it wasn’t more widely known until trans issues were recently pushed into the spotlight. A future prevailing social norm that you and I haven’t heard of now probably already exists within an even more obscure community who has yet to gain much visibility.

    • Bugmaster says:
      February 12, 2018 at 2:06 am

      Oh wow, I had no idea. Saints Cyril and Methodius are pretty much the only saints that I can unequivocally respect (granted, there may be lots of saints I just don’t know about). They were canonized not for getting martyred, or for advancing their version of religious dogma, or for conquering territory; but for essentially uplifting an entire people into full sapience. Few individuals throughout history have that honor.

      • Anonymous says:

      • Winter Shaker says:
        February 12, 2018 at 2:42 am

        Well, into full literacy, at least 🙂
        But the cool / weird factoid that is not so well known is that the alphabet that they invented is cool and complicated, with lots of little loops, but is not used today. When later scholars devised a simpler, largely Greek-based script for the Old Church Slavonic language, they named it in honour of Cyril, with the odd effect that he is an actual inventor-of-an-alphabet who is today best ‘known’ as the inventor of a particular alphabet he probably didn’t actually invent.

        >pazcki

        Swap the c and z. Paczki (boxes). Pączki (donuts). Pronunciation approximation: pohn-chkee.

        • AlphaGamma says:
          February 12, 2018 at 9:06 am

          Also there’s the common US-English-speaker issue of assuming that a foreign plural is the singular and adding an -s to the end. “Pierogies” is fairly common and sometimes simplified further to “perogies”, and I’ve also heard “gnocchis”.

          I did once see the reverse (in a video game which should have known better)- the writers assumed that the Russian word strelets, referring to a type of early modern infantry soldier, was plural and invented the nonsense singular “strelet”.

          • Sniffnoy says:
            February 12, 2018 at 12:08 pm

            Oh yeah, that’s a known phenomenon. See e.g. the etymologies of “cherry” and “pea”.

          • gbdub says:
            February 13, 2018 at 7:49 am

            Traditional Paczki are richer and denser than typical yeast donuts. A good paczek should be heavier, darker, and a bit crisper on the outside than a Berliner.

            They tend to have more egg and fat in the dough, plus a bit of grain alcohol that keeps the oil from penetrating quite as deep. The idea was they’d have a lot of everything you weren’t supposed to eat during Lent, to use it up.

            But that’s just like my opinion, man – this is one of those things where everyone’s grandma has a slightly different recipe so there’s no “right” answer. They are special donuts, but they are still donuts.

          • SamChevre says:
            February 13, 2018 at 12:29 pm

            They are somewhat homeomorphic to jelly doughnuts, but the dough part is as good as the jelly part.

            They are a yeasted dough, so not that sweet–and the jam filling is most commonly prune/plum or rose jam (sometimes it is made with both rose hips and rose petals/rosewater, sometimes just one or the other.) I brought prune, rose, and apricot from the local Polish hole-in-the-wall bakery.

            Imagine a really good jelly doughnut, with relatively little filling. (I’d say a pączki the size of a flattened tennis ball has maybe 2 tablespoons of jam.)

  41. DunnoWhatToDo says:
    February 11, 2018 at 11:34 pm

    My best bud has a birthday this weekend. I don’t know the other people there; what are some good strategies for establishing a social connection with the people there?

    • Bugmaster says:
      February 11, 2018 at 11:42 pm

      If you’re like me, stand in the corner and sip out of your red plastic cup dejectedly.

      But you could also ask your bud to introduce you to some people, if lurking is not your style…

    • Anonymous says:
      February 12, 2018 at 1:59 am

      1. Approach random stranger.
      2. “Hello! I’m Jimbob, Bud’s friend.”
      3. Smalltalk from there.
      4. Go to 1.

      • Bugmaster says:
        February 12, 2018 at 2:07 am

        I don’t think you fully appreciate how difficult point #3 is for some people. Myself included.

        • Anonymous says:
          February 12, 2018 at 2:22 am

          What exactly are you having trouble with concerning smalltalk?

        • phil says:
          February 12, 2018 at 4:16 am

          On Marginal Revolution Tyler Cowan has made a couple of references to trying to organize knowledge according to place, with one of the benefits being that nearly anyone you come across can teach you something about the places they’ve been, so that makes for good small talk fodder ( see #5 http://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2018/01/tyler-cowens-12-rules-life.html and #2 http://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2018/02/advantages-organizing-knowledge-terms-country-place.html)

          Personally I find ‘So have you seen any interesting movies lately?’ to be a good neutral conversation starter that works across a large cross section of the population (it has a lot of natural follow up questions, you can ask them to describe the movie to you if you’re not familiar with it, you can segue to topics that seem related to the plot of the movie, of similar movies, or other movies in the general genre, it gives you a fair amount of conversational optionality.

          I find small talk hard as well though.

        • Parfay says:
          February 12, 2018 at 8:35 am

          Huh. This breakdown makes me realize it’s #1 and #2 I find abjectly terrifying, the actual conversation is usually fine.

          Here’s my smalltalk advice, for what it’s worth:

          -To me, most of the purpose of smalltalk is to find your way to a topic both people find interesting. Seemingly mundane talk about the weather or such can get you there, it’s a game where each question or answer has some chance of giving you a clue about something you have in common or something that would be fun to discuss in more detail. Some kinds of questions have a higher information return than others but generally if you can keep it moving and express interest, you can often make your way there.

          -Sometimes I can’t tell if someone who’s not picking up conversational openings really doesn’t want to talk to me and is trying to end the conversation, or if they are just “bad at smalltalk.” If I had a way of knowing they did want to talk to me but were just having a hard time with conversation flow, I wouldn’t mind working a bit harder at keeping it going. So expressing enthusiasm/interest even if you don’t know what to say next is helpful.

        • Conrad Honcho says:
          February 13, 2018 at 12:00 pm

          FORM. Family Occupation Recreation Motivation. Follow up the FOR questions with an M question, because those are open-ended and can get people to ramble on.

          “Where is your family from?” “Oh, why did you want to move here/there?”

          “What do you do for a living?” “Oh, why did you want to get into that?”

          “What do you do for fun?” “Oh that’s neat, how did you get started with that?”

          At some people they should mention something you have in common and can jump off from there. If you get through a dozen of these questions and don’t have anything in common, well maybe it wasn’t meant to be and you should try somebody else.

      • James says:
        February 12, 2018 at 10:56 am

        if we’re really doing smalltalk for Absolute Beginners, then some more good stock lines are:

        “So, how do you know [mutual friend]?” or “So, who do you know here?” (then ramble about their connection, or mention how you know them, and ramble about that)
        “What part of [city] do you live in?” (then ramble about that area, what’s good about it, what’s bad about it, how it compares to other areas)
        “What do you do?” (then–you guessed it–ramble on that topic for a bit)

        (edit: beaten by Aapje on some of these)

        Spending most of the conversation asking questions is kinda like easy mode: it probably won’t make you seem unusually interesting or charming, but it probably won’t bore people or (worse) make them think you’re a boor, either. (Easy mode isn’t necessarily a bad thing if that’s what your socials skills levels are at.)

        Some people use ‘deep’ questions to bypass smalltalk and try to jump straight to forging a deep connection. (A few weeks ago someone I just met asked me what I’m most afraid of, for instance.) Some people can pull this sort of thing off but I wouldn’t suggest it to someone who’s socially unsure of themselves.

    • Aapje says:
      February 12, 2018 at 3:56 am

      @DunnoWhatToDo

      The easy part is that, unlike with long term acquaintances, you have lots to discover about each other.

      The hard part that you and they may not like what they discover and so information management (what to divulge and what to ask) is not so easy.

      So my first advice is to analyze the ‘opposition.’ Your first clue is that these people like your friend, which suggests that they are in some way like him. So topics that you like to talk about with your friend may be productive. However, keep in mind that other people may not like your friend for why you like your friend & they may interact with him differently than you.

      So what you can do is analyze your friend (both his traits that you like and don’t you don’t particularly like). Then at the party you can try to categorize people, based on this information. Then you may be able to determine topics that are likely to be productive (for example, based on physique and/or dress, you may be able to identify the people who do sports with your friend). The optimal outcome is to find a topic that is mutually interesting, but if you want to sacrifice your personal enjoyment to make yourself be liked, you can find a topic that only the other person likes. This can be a very good strategy for people who have trouble with social contact. Many people are very willing to talk your ears off about their favorite topic with minimal prodding.

      A bit of research into interesting tidbits about topics that your analysis indicates would find an audience, can enable you to (re)start conversations by means of anecdote (‘Have you heard about…’).

      —

      A simpler strategy that is generically useful, even no prior analysis/information, is to ask about ‘default’ topics, like:
      – What do you do?
      – What are your hobbies?
      – Where do you know my friend from?
      – Were you born here? (may not be an appropriate question for some crowds)

      Of course, the trick is then to ‘riff’ off the responses, which is non-trivial.

      • fion says:
        February 12, 2018 at 8:08 am

        I think this is pretty good advice. With regard to ‘riffing’ off the responses, a strategy I find effective is to concentrate on asking things, and not worrying about whether or not I’m saying much. Most people like talking about themselves. Of course, thinking of questions is still non-trivial.

        A little bit of nodding/smiling/”oh yeah?”/laughing/”sure”/etc. depending on the tone of what they’re talking about goes a long way in keeping them talking.

        And if you can, try to actually be interested in them/what they’re talking about! That way you don’t have to act. 😛

        • Bugmaster says:
          February 12, 2018 at 5:29 pm

          Don’t get me wrong, it is good advice, but executing correctly on it is still difficult (unless you’ve been blessed with extraversion from birth). When executed incorrectly, this protocol can easily turn into an interrogation, which can make people instantly hate you.

          • andrewflicker says:
            February 14, 2018 at 7:52 am

            You’d be surprised- most people love talking about themselves, so even if you end up asking the questions interrogation-style, it’s rarely a faux pas.

    • liskantope says:
      February 12, 2018 at 4:13 am

      I find in these situations that asking “So how do you know [the birthday boy]?” is a pretty good icebreaker. After all a priori the only thing you have in common is knowing him, and conversation can start from discussing how you came to know him and/or what your impressions about him are.

    • Ketil says:
      February 12, 2018 at 4:48 am

      Explain the situation to your friend, and ask if he could introduce you to people – e.g. someone you have a shared interest with. It’s what a host is supposed to do anyway, IMO.

      • AG says:
        February 12, 2018 at 3:43 pm

        Second this. I visited a family member for a holiday they were spending with a friend’s family. They introduced me to the one other person at the gathering that was into geeky topics.
        Otherwise, I spent a good amount of time petting the family dog and shamelessly using that as my conversation springboard for anyone who came by. Since it was a potluck situation, praising the food/cooks was also a good springboard.

    • veeloxtrox says:
      February 12, 2018 at 9:52 am

      General small talk tip: People like talking about themselves, let them. If you are lucky they mention something you are interested in and you go from there, if not… idk

    • AG says:
      February 12, 2018 at 3:39 pm

      My trick to smalltalk is piggybacking. I let the extroverts of the group start the conversations. Then, I lurk and eavesdrop on the various groups until I find one that I can contribute to, and then just jump in with said contribution. Usually people won’t side-eye the jumping in, unless it’s a very personal-gossip topic, in which case I probably won’t have anything to contribute, anyways. Often I can get knee-deep into discussion this way, without ever learning anyone’s names or introducing myself.

      Given that your party is this weekend, the Olympics will be topical and interesting from any variety of talking angles. Ask if they’re following the games, and if so which sport, and then voila. If they’re not following the games, then you can ask what they’re following in lieu of the games, and then voila.

  42. LadyJane says:
    February 11, 2018 at 11:11 pm

    A thought exercise I’ve been posting to libertarian groups lately: You live in an alternate reality where, instead of Republicans and Democrats, the American political landscape was divided between the two political parties described below. Both of these parties combine some elements of modern conservatism and modern liberalism, but not in a particularly libertarian way, and they’re very anti-libertarian in some regards. Assuming that you *have* to support one of them (voting is legally required in this world, and third parties don’t exist), which would you choose?

    Populist Party: Combines Trump-style right-populism with Bernie-style left-populism. Protectionist (supports high tariffs and subsidies for American companies that employ American workers), isolationist (anti-war, wants to pull out of foreign conflicts and greatly defund the military, wants to pull out of trade organizations and agreements like NAFTA and the TPP), anti-immigration (wants to deport all illegal immigrants and make it harder for them to get in, and greatly reduce legal immigration, especially from ‘dangerous’ countries), pro-welfare but only for “real Americans” (supports universal healthcare and guaranteed basic income, but only for natural-born American citizens), strongly favors a states’ rights approach to social issues (e.g. abortion, LGBT issues, drug policies), supports some restrictions on free speech to prevent the spread of “anti-American” sentiments (e.g. criminalizing flag burning, regulating mass media that challenges traditional American/Christian values, monitoring people who support Marxist or Islamist ideologies).

    Globalist Party: Combines Republican-style neoconservatism with Democrat-style neoliberalism. Favors free trade (low tariffs, no tax penalties for companies that outsource work to other countries, heavy involvement in trade organizations/agreements like NAFTA and the TPP), supports heavy military spending, encourages frequent military interventionism for the sake of “promoting democracy” and securing American interests, pro-immigration (wants to make it easier for people to immigrate here legally and for illegal immigrants to become citizens), wants to cut funding to social safety net programs (e.g. welfare, social security, public healthcare), very socially liberal on women’s issues and LGBT Issues (pro-choice, supports gay marriage, etc.) but vehemently opposed to drug legalization, supports some restrictions on free speech and free association to prevent discrimination against marginalized groups (e.g. outlawing hate speech, preventing businesses from refusing to serve/hire people based on race or religion or sexual orientation).

    • Bugmaster says:
      February 11, 2018 at 11:24 pm

      I’m not a libertarian, but still: I find your question confusing. What’s the point of listing all those clauses ? I understand that you’re trying to present some dichotomies, e.g. between economic vs. social liberties, and between nationalism vs. globalism, but I’m not sure why you are confounding them together.

      Also, I believe that a true libertarian would refuse to vote at all, and go live in the hills at the first opportunity. Being forced to vote for positions you disagree with goes against the very core of libertarian beliefs (ok, less so than taxation, but still).

      • LadyJane says:
        February 12, 2018 at 2:23 am

        What’s the point of listing all those clauses ? I understand that you’re trying to present some dichotomies, e.g. between economic vs. social liberties, and between nationalism vs. globalism, but I’m not sure why you are confounding them together.

        Libertarians are widely seen as being “fiscally conservative and socially liberal,” and the Populist Party is meant to be the inverse of that. It’s also something that I’m honestly a little surprised doesn’t exist already, given how socially conservative people tend to be poor and would seemingly benefit from more left-wing economic policies, at least in the short term. We may be seeing the beginnings of such a movement now, given that a lot of modern conservatives seem to be moving toward the center on economic issues while simultaneously moving further right on social issues.

        • John Schilling says:
          February 12, 2018 at 6:53 am

          Libertarians are widely seen as being “fiscally conservative and socially liberal,” and the Populist Party is meant to be the inverse of that.

          I don’t see the fiscal conservatism in either of your parties. One of them wants to spend lots of money on welfare and subsidies, one of them wants to spend lots of money on foreign wars, neither of them wants to raise income or other revenue-generating taxes. Can you guess what happens when these two parties sit across the table and negotiate a budget they can both agree to?

          Hint: You’ve seen it in action recently. Also,

          Assuming that you *have* to support one of them (voting is legally required in this world, and third parties don’t exist), which would you choose?

          The ruling party of the country most likely to fire thermonuclear missiles at the capital of the one you posit?

          OK, that’s a bit harsh, particularly given that you’ve pretty much guaranteed the country will destroy itself in the long run. But mandatory voting is an abomination that ought to be seen only in communist hellholes; AFIK the only respectable nation that actually enforces such a mandate is Australia, and they at least let you turn in a spoiled ballot if you’re not satisfied with any of their dozen formally represented political parties.

            Aussie here, the days of us not understanding what all the fuss is about are certainly coming to a middle. Here its a policy supported by majority of aussies left or right.

        • hyperboloid says:
          February 14, 2018 at 5:29 am

          chaffing at Clinton’s interventionism in the Balkans.

          Why?

          Bosnia, and Kosovo seem to be the best possible outcomes for US intervention. We stopped a pretty odious regime from slaughtering a lot of people, and headed off what was likely to turn into a very serious Jihadist insurgency. All in all, an easy nearly zero cost win for the good guys.

          • Conrad Honcho says:

          • John Schilling says:
            February 14, 2018 at 8:17 am

            …and headed off what was likely to turn into a very serious Jihadist insurgency.

            I’d wager that insurgency would have been crushed into something of minor and local significance if NATO had stayed out of it, left the Serbs and their Russian allies to deal with it.

            As you say, we did a great deal of local good at low cost on that occasion. But we also set the precedent that Europe can effectively decide to start wars that the US has to fight. That didn’t work nearly so well in e.g. Libya, and I’m not sure we’re done with it yet.

    • quanta413 says:
      February 12, 2018 at 8:08 am

      The first party, if I think it really won’t engage in scads of foreign wars or initiate arms races. On almost every other topic you listed, I find the second party’s position better or at least only equally bad. But the military issues are that important.

      In practice, I might end up changing my mind about how bad foreign interventions are if after observing a U.S. that stayed disengaged for ~15-20 years it turned out world order obviously collapsed and clearly wouldn’t have if the U.S. kept engaging in wars. But I find that pretty implausible. And even then I’m not sure. I’m not a utilitarian.

      Also in practice, I don’t expect to see a serious militarily isolationist party in power in the U.S. during the next 20 years probably much longer.

    • anonymousskimmer says:
      February 12, 2018 at 8:24 am

      For those saying anti-war: Is this because of the benefit to those in other lands, or the benefit to the US people?

      I was considering the pro-immigration one as more likely to have reciprocal treaties making it easy for me to emigrate to a better country, and contrasting this to the anti-way party as better for others and maybe I should take the hit to the personal freedoms I care most about out of duty to the greater good.

      • ilikekittycat says:
        February 12, 2018 at 5:24 pm

        Both/I don’t really see how you separate them?

        I spent time in Berlin during the Bush administration, and being in college at the time, I expected all the tips about travelling to Europe to be true, having to pretend you are a Canadian, all the scorn, barely acknowledged by service workers who think you are a fat hamburger, etc.

        What I found when I got there, even as I was hanging out with far left art studio kids? They hated Bush, but had a far less cynical view of Americans than I did. John F Kennedy might as well have given the “Ich bin ein Berliner” speech the year before for how much they genuinely believed America was a force for good, with good people, who sometimes ended up with idiots in charge.

        American hard power sometimes works for us, but frequently blows up in our face. American diplomacy/persuasion/culture is a 10x better weapon at making people like us and want to be like us, and benefit our status. I am flabbergasted every time I think about how it took America 10 years to go from “Wow, we brought down the Iron Curtain with soft power and finally achieved the impossible” to “actors in international relations respond to only two things: economic incentives and force”

      • SamChevre says:
        February 12, 2018 at 5:44 pm

        For me, both. My father (Vietnam draftee veteran, very much an ex-hippie) commented after 9-11 “we’ve done so much to so many–why are we surprised if when someone does something to us.” Leaving other people alone is better for them and for us.

    • The Nybbler says:
      February 12, 2018 at 8:30 am

      How do these parties feel about suicide? Because with those choices, I think it’s an option I would want to keep open.

      They’re both terrible on free speech, obviously. Which is worse depends on implementation details; both “hate speech” and “challenges traditional American/Christian values” can be blank checks.

      The Populists win on social issues, mostly because of drug legalization (though the culture war shows us that being liberal on women’s issues and LGBT issues can be very anti-liberty also).

      The Globalists are a clear win on economic issues, except for the military spending.

      For the military, I think the Populist stance is probably not tenable. The US still has enemies. The Globalists are far too hawkish, but better to have an empire than to be weak.

      So I’d go for the Globalists. Especially if they’ll let me keep my .45 just in case. With the caveat that I’m not sure either party has a consistent position as you’ve described it. For instance, in the real world, public healthcare is often claimed to be part of “women’s issues”.
